results.description:
The private practice industry has seen major changes over the last decade, and some of these changes make it virtually impossible for clinicians to survive as private practitioners. Do you know how your private practice will endure in this economy? Do you think it is possible to make enough money without working a full-time job at someone else’s business or organization? This workshop will teach you how to find the hidden opportunities that exists and how to be more profitable in your private practice.

This week we will discuss the importance of systems and structures for a small business. Systems and structure will help streamline your business. Areas of focus will be: phone calls, clients, creating effective client policies (informed consent, financial obligations, and appointment cancellations)


Reserve your spot today! Only 30 slots available!
results.name: From Pain to Profit: What Successful Practitioners Do Differently

results.description:
Some of you missed our latest webinar on bootstrapping and requested a repeat, so we will do the same webinar again. Feel free to join us if you missed it, or you feel like hearing it again.   

Building a Startup by bootstrapping is one the most important tasks of any founder, regardless if they are raising money or trying to create a business that becomes profitable on their own.

This event is a Free Online Webinar, happening via Blab, an application and webpage allowing video live conversations. The link to register and participate in the Blab session is: https://blab.im/startupblink-building-a-startup-by-bootstrapping

This StartupBlink lecture by our CEO (Eli David) will focus on methods for entrepreneurs to build and grow a sustainable startup themselves without spending time on raising money from professional investors. Among other subjects, we will discuss how to generate sales, find loans and grants, generate organic media attention, and more. Eli will also discuss his status as a digital nomad who constantly changes locations while expanding his startups.

This lecture is brought to you by our sister company, Lingolearn, an online language school where you can learn any language you wish with our private tutors from around the world. We have a special offer of 1 hour lesson in more than 20 languages with a private tutor for$15, only for StartupBlink meetup members. The lesson is money back guaranteed (no questions asked), so in case you are not happy with the lesson, we will  get your money back immediately. Time to learn the language you always dreamed of at www.Store.Lingolearn.com

If you missed our previous online webinar on Getting Traction for your Startup you can watch it here  
https://blab.im/startupblink-getting-traction-for-your-startup

Special request from us, please don't forget to add your startup or organization @ http://www.startupblink.com and join our closed startup group at: https://www.facebook.com/groups/startupblink/
results.name: How to build a Startup without Investors by Bootstrapping

results.description:
This is a TENTATIVE meetup. If we can get at least 3 total we will meet for golf. So replay “yes” to let me know if you’re pretty sure you can play golf next Thurs. (4/21). Let me have your tentative “yes” by Tues. (4/19) by 9:00 AM. I’ll then make reservations for 4/21 and ask for your final (and definite) “yes”.

This meetup is open to everybody. In other words, breaking 100 is not a have to have (although nice to have). Where we plan to play (Hyatt Hills) is also the shortest of any of the courses we play.

I’ve listed a start time of 12:30. If you have a preference for another time let me know given that this meetup is still tentative.

For those not familiar with Hyatt Hills it’s a nine hold course. But we can play 18 holes (due to a different pin and tee box location for the second round of nine). Hyatt also has a nice practice range (including a chipping area and a practice sand trap). Two restaurants are on site. So come earlier if you want to practice some first. I’m sure I will.


The weather forecast for 4/21 is text book perfect: 72 degrees and sunny.
- - - - - - - - - - -
BACKGROUND ON OUR NEW PROCEDURE
Going forward, we will organize our golf outing with a two-step process as being done here (as well as was done last week). In other words, we will first do a nose count of who thinks they can come. After the nose count, we will finalize golf reservations and ask people to firmly commit. 

This new two-step procedure is being done so that we can manage reservations more smoothly. For example, a while back I made reservations for 8 people. However, only 3 were actually able to come. When I cancelled reservations for 5 people I’m sure I burned up a little goodwill with the course. Plus cancelling at the last minute puts me at a slight risk of getting charged for the cancellations. 

So my apologies for making your “yes” to a golf outing a two-step process. But I think this will work better. Your thoughts/suggestions are welcome.

results.description:
Docker 101

Date: Thursday, April 21, 2016
Time: 10am PDT / 1pm EDT
Register Here

Early adopters report "easier replication, faster deployment and lower configuration and operating costs" of applications that involve Docker containers - an open platform that allows developers and sysadmins to build, ship and execute distributed applications.

Not surprisingly then, a groundswell of organizations are interested in evaluating Docker containers in proof-of-concept initiatives and/or pilot projects. The transition to production use, however, introduces additional requirements as Docker containers need to be incorporated into existing IT infrastructures and (ultimately) integrated into application workflows.

In answering the 5 Ws and one H, the aim of this webinar is to provide a technical overview and demonstration of Docker and to frame its use within the context of High Performance Computing and Big Data Analytics.

Join us to learn all about Docker.
Interested, but can't attend? Register anyway and we'll send you the recording.

Agenda:
• What are Docker containers - relative to physical machines, VMs and other containers?
• Who is responsible for Docker containers?
• Why and when were Docker containers created?
• What is the container ecosystem?
• Where is use of containers appropriate and not appropriate?
▸ HPC applications?
▸ Big Data Analytics? Specifically, Spark-based applications?
▸ On premise and in the cloud?
▸ Is running Docker different in HPC versus microservice-based applications?
• How can I make use of Docker containers?
▸ How can I containerize my application?
▸ How can I create, or make use of, a Docker image?
▸ How can I run Docker containers as I do other types of workloads?
• Getting Started and Next Steps Reserve your complimentary spot now, as space is limited!
results.name: [webinar] Docker 101

results.description:
</a>

Join us for a Scratch Educator Meetup on Thursday, April 21 at the South Bronx Early College Academy! The meetup is free and includes dinner.

What's a Scratch Educator Meetup?

Scratch: a <a href="http://scratch.mit.edu">free tool for exploring computational creativity by programming interactive media (like stories, games, animations, and simulations) and sharing those creations with others online, used by millions of people all around the world

Scratch Educator: a teacher who wants to support computational creativity in the classroom and beyond, helping learners—from elementary school to high school, across curricular areas and settings—imagine, program, and share with Scratch 

Scratch Educator Meetup: a gathering of Scratch Educators who want to learn with and from each other, sharing their ideas and strategies for supporting computational creativity in all its forms 

What will we be doing at the meetup?

If you're new to the meetup format, here's what they are and how they work. Meetups are informal gatherings for educators who work with (or are interested in working with) Scratch. The meetups are organized into three parts:

1. We start with networking over light refreshments, getting to know fellow attendees and sharing what people want to explore during the meetup.

2. We collaboratively decide how to structure our learning and then form small groups based on our different interests. Maybe you want to have a discussion about classroom strategies or get more practice with Scratch—or something else entirely. Feel free to move between groups if the session that you're in isn't working for you.

3. We gather as a whole group for dinner and group sharing. You might pose a question to discuss with the group, or share something from your classroom. This is a great time to inspire and be inspired.

Want to know more about meetups? Check out this recap of our recent meetup in Washington D.C.!

What should I bring?

Curiosity. And a laptop that supports Flash will be helpful for the hands-on activities. If you're new to Scratch, you can check it out at http://scratch.mit.edu

We look forward to meeting up with you!
Kelly Powers and Ric Campbell of the SBECACS
Karen Brennan and Willa Peragine of the Harvard ScratchEd Team
results.name: NYC Scratch Educator Meetup

results.description:
Updated March 7th, 2016

Given the warmth that has descended upon NYC, I am making Tuesdays/Thursdays active again, but at 5pm.

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. Our main location is Riverside Park, with Morningside and Booker T Washington as backups.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 5pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)
- Thursdays at 5pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

BOOKER T. WASHINGTON DETAILS

This location is between 107th & 108th Streets just West of Columbus Avenue. It's on the backside of the high school. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. 

+++

OTHER SEASONS...

WINTER (Nov - Feb)

During the colder months we generally play two times a week depending on weather. Our main location is Riverside Park with Morningside as a backup.

There are two days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
*Tuesdays/Thursdays at 6pm games don't last long due to decreasing sunlight.

FALL (Sep - Oct)

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave)
- Sundays at 4pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

results.description:
Intranet My i - Bring your Intranet to IBM i for FREE

Zend Server for IBM i, MySQL and Drupal offer an open source solution that can leverage existing hardware and software investment in IBM i without requiring a capital expenditure. Are you tired of the “web team” at your company getting all the glory? Attend this session to learn how quick and easy it is to install an open source PHP application on your IBM i. You can join the millions of companies leveraging Drupal for open source content management and host your company intranet on IBM I.

Exploring DB2 Data Access in PHP 

The DB2 extension built in to PHP is a curious beast and works well right out of the gate. But could there be more to look at? In this presentation we explore the basics of the DB2 connection and review examples of how to manipulate library lists. In addition, we’ll explore concepts of standard connect & persistent connections and review when it’s best to use each. Also an exploration of performance optimization techniques and recent changes will be reviewed.

results.description:
Come Join us for a Bike Ride after work starting on the Walkway over the Hudson, crossing over to the Hudson Valley Rail Trail and then back over the Walkway over the Hudson to the Dutchess County Rail Trail. Please CLICK the links throughout this description for maps and/or website information.

The entire ride is paved and open to all levels.  A Road Bike or Hybrid is recommended but a Mountain Bike can be used if you don't mind going slower.

We will meet at 5:45pm at the Poughkeepsie Entrance at 61 Parker Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601

Parking Fee: There is Free Parking in the dirt lot bordering the road with no time restrictions. (The paved lot behind that requires a NYS Empire Passport or $5. for up to 4 hours and you must be out by sunset - I don't recommend parking in the NYS Parks "paved" lot for this event)


Have all your gear ready and plan to start promptly by 6:00pm.

We will all ride together until roughly 8:00pm.  That should give us enough time to cover the Walkway over the Hudson, the Hudson Valley Rail Trail and a good portion of the Dutchess County Rail Trail.

At roughly 7:15pm we turn around from wherever we are and return to our start point.


MANDATORY GEAR:

• Road Bike, Hybrid or Mountain Bike

• Bicycle Helmet

• Headlamp with spare batteries

RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Clear eye Protection (safety glasses - for bugs, dirt, etc.)

• Related maps, a compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.

• Bike Pump

• Tire Patch Kit and/or Spare Tube

PLEASE INSPECT YOUR BIKE PRIOR TO ARRIVAL TO INSURE THE FOLLOWING:

• Proper Tire Inflation

• Lubricated chain

• Properly Shifting gears

• Functional Brakes that don't rub rim or tire when released.


FOR MORE INFO ON THE PARK VISIT:

https://walkway.org/gwe


For those who would like to join me for some Food after the ride I will be heading over to the West Indies Restaurant (Venue subject to change based on group preference)

West Indies Restaurant

105 Main St


Poughkeepsie, NY 12601


(845)[masked] 


Specialties

Jerk chicken, Oxtail, Curry Goat/chicken, stew beef, stew chicken, jerk pork...served with your choice of Rice & peas or white rice, Dumplings, yams, bananas...steam cabbage or mixed vegetable on the side.
PATTIES..BEEF, VEG, CHICKEN, Spinach
Natural jamaican drinks. Carrot Juice, Irish Moss

History

Established in 2000.

Family owned and operated...We take pride in our meals..everything cook fresh daily..known as the # 1 authentic jamaican food around town..come in and enjoy...

results.description:
Share a Stitch

So whomever wants to share a stitch they are jazzed about let me know and and come prepared to demonstrate and laugh out loud while we stitch ourselves into a frenzy trying out your shiny new toy. 

Help, I'm stuck!

So there's this project we all have that would be totally perfect except there's one part of it that is an infernal nuisance and has us stopped in our tracks. Help a sister out. Calling all stitching ninjas! 

Let's put our heads together and help make one more great embroidery or needlepoint happen in this world. One question a member please, and let's vet them beforehand so there are no repeats.

Best Stores Ever

Ok, I am asking  you to divulge trade secrets. You know,  that PLACE that has that STUFF you can't get anywhere else and for such a bargain! Come armed with all the information we may need to go on our very own stitching supply safari.  Who knows? this topic just screams FIELD TRIP to me.

Along the same lines, member Kim Kotary has suggested a supply swap. Items bought, and shunted aside for something even more fabulous and are just sitting there making you feel like a Imelda Marcos or someone in need of an intervention. Stay Tuned - Kim has kindly offered to spearhead her nifty thrifty idea.
results.name: Share a Stitch - Help, I'm Stuck! - Best Stores Ever

results.description:
CONFESSION TIME: A few years ago, Russell Peters performed within 15 miles of where I used to live. The tickets were ridiculously expensive at $100+ and up. I couldn't justify the cost so I opted not to watch him, even though I'd been following him on Youtube since he started his career. I squealed when I saw that he's going to be within a 3-mile radius from me and it doesn't cost an arm and a leg to watch him work his magic!


You guys, I'm so excited @#%@%@%@%

---------------------------------------------------

WHAT IS THE LEVITY LIVE CLUB?


At the Levity Live Comedy Club, renowned comedians such as Kevin Nealon and Susie Essman have graced the same stage as up-and-coming comics including Elliot Chang and Sam Morril.

---------------------------------------------------

WHO IS RUSSELL PETERS?

</a> <a href="https://s3.amazonaws.com/webassets.ticketmob.com/LS/images/ShowPosters/6E36F01D-993B-0B98-067E007DFA74D26A.jpg">

RUSSELL PETERS is an international comedy rock star who regularly sells out arenas all over the world. Russell is just wrapping up his fourth sold-out world-wide tour, The Almost Famous Tour, which celebrates 25 years in the business. His previous tour, Notorious, became the highest attended comedy tour ever in Australia, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Lebanon, South Africa, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong and his home country of Canada. Among the many venues Peters has sold out are Madison Square Garden, Radio City Music Hall, LA’s Nokia Theatre, the Sydney Opera House and back-to-back nights at London’s famed O-2 Arena. Peters was the first comic to sell out Canada’s Air Canada center, which he has now done seven times and in November 2012, he became the first stand-up comic to perform at Brooklyn’s Barclays Centre with over 13,000 fans in attendance. As a result, Peters is regular on the Forbes List of top ten highest earning comics, ranking as high as number three in 2013. His comedy has generated over 120 million views on YouTube.

Peters has transitioned into both small and big screens, having recently been a judge alongside Roseanne Barr and Keenan Ivory Wayans for NBC’s reboot of Last Comic Standing, and lending his voice to the animated feature,Ribbit, and to numerous episodes of the iconic animated Fox television show Family Guy and Bob’s Burgers. He was also awarded a Gemini Award, Canada’s version of the Emmy, for hosting the country’s Juno Awards Show. Other notable film roles include the recent Jon Favreau directed indie smash hit Chef, the 2011 sci-fi movie Source Code, alongside Jake Gyllenhaal, the Canadian ice hockey hit Breakaway, where he also served as Executive Producer and the Eva Mendes indie, Girl in Progress alongside Mendes and Patricia Arquette. Peters has appeared on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno, The Jimmy Fallon Show, Jimmy Kimmel Live, Lopez Tonight, Craig Ferguson, the Queen Latifah Show and Def Comedy Jam.

Russell was recently featured in a Variety article celebrating his 25 years in comedy: http://variety.com/2015/biz/spotlight/russell-peters-25-years-in-comedy-1201539908/

--------------------------------------------------

**EVENT DETAILS**

HOW TO BUY TICKETS: Purchase your ticket here:http://levitylive.com/event.cfm?cart&id=438778. Note that buying your ticket in advance is YOUR responsibility. I highly recommend not waiting until the week before to purchase your ticket!


COST OF THE EVENT: $45/ticket, $15-25/person for food (variable)

The Levity Live Comedy Club requires a two-item minimum food and/or drink purchase per person. Check out their menu here: http://nyack.levitylive.com/FOOD--DRINK.


Shows are 18+. All guests MUST have valid, government issued photo ID. No Alcohol will be served at any Table that has a Guest under 21 years of age unless a Parent is present. All Seating is on a first come first served basis.

TIME: According to the internet, the earlier we get there, the better seats we will have. So even though the event itself is at 7:30PM, lets meet at 6PM at Chipotle, which is right next to the Levity Live. Depending on how many people RSVP, we can get dinner reservations.


PARKING: The best entrance is via TheEATery or Target.

---------------------------------------------------


UNRELATED TIP: Check out Levity Live groupons at https://www.groupon.com/deals/gl-levity-live

results.description:
Please join us for an exciting evening to learn more about  Apache Flink from Stephan Ewen who is committer/VP in the Apache Flink project and co-founder/CTO of  Data Artisans.

Sponsors: 


• Workville is hosting the event. 

• MapR is offering pizza and beverage. 

Schedule: 

6:00 pm - 6:25 pm : Networking, pizza and drinks 

6:25 pm - 6:30 pm : Welcome by Rassul Fazelat

6:30 pm - 8:00 pm: Talk by Stephan Ewen

Talk description:  The talk will consist of two parts:

1. The first part discusses some fundamental patterns and problems behind continuous streaming applications in general, and how we built Apache Flink 1.0 to handle these problems. The talk will dig into questions around latency critical applications, fault tolerance and processing guarantees (exactly once, how to achieve then end-to-end), into processing data streams by "event time", or "processing time", handling out-of-order event streams, and about migrating, repairing, or versioning live streaming programs.

2. The second part of the talk is a technical deep dive into Apache Flink, discussing how the functionality discussed from a user and application point of view is actually implemented. The talk will cover the integration with Apache Kafka, the mechanisms behind fault-tolerance and high-availability, event time and windowing, savepoints and program reinstatements, as well as techniques for managing large online state.

Bio: Stephan Ewen is a committer in the Apache Flink project and co-founder and CTO of Data Artisans. Before founding Data Artisans, Stephan was leading the development of Flink since the early days of the project. Stephan holds a PhD in Computer Science from TU Berlin.

results.description:
Join us Thursday, April 21st for a great demo on container image security with CoreOS, makers of Linux for massive server deployments. CoreOS engineer Quentin Machu will be presenting and demoing Clair. 


Clair is an open-source container image security analyzer and was recently launched by CoreOS for production workloads. This is a powerful and extensible tool that inspects container images for known security flaws and enables developers to build services that scan containers for security threats and vulnerabilities. Come to see how it works and get involved with the development.

Apprenda will provide free pizza and a wide selection of ice cold beer to all attendees.

Agenda: 

6:00 - 6:30pm: Socializing

6:30 - 7:00pm: Quentin Machu from CoreOS demos Clair and talks about the latest at CoreOS

7:00 - 8:00pm: Socializing


WE HAVE SEATING FOR 30! Please arrive early if you need to sit during the demo. There is plenty of space to socialize beyond the seating area. 


Check out photos from our last Meetup event with Google here: http://www.meetup.com/Container-Orchestration-NYC/events/229292820/

results.description:
All Bisexual, Non-monosxual, and all other Queer-identified and Bi-friendly people are invited to come join people from the greater NYC Area in a lively topic oriented discussion at  BiRequest's famously open, non-judgmental, safe space. If you can't make it to the meeting, feel free to join everyone afterward around "eight-fifteenish" for dinner.

about us: Thanks to the dedication and hard work of many good bisexual folk, BiRequest is a bisexual social discussion group serving the New York City metropolitan area since January 1994. We provide a safe space for bisexuals and bi-friendly people to gather and discuss issues of importance to us.

We're a co-ed group for adults from 18 to 80-plus who meet twice a month (starting in 2016, every 1st Monday and 3rd Thursday evening) at NYC's LGBT Center in the West Village. The meetings are moderated and focused on a discussion topic but not limited to that week's topic.

After the discussion group session, at 8 o'clock we go to dinner at a nearby, reasonably-priced restaurant for socializing and more informal discussion. We also have occasional social events such as movie nights, parties, and much more. Join us for a meeting or event and find the community you've been looking for!

People who can't make it to the meeting are invited to join our private online group BiRequest on Yahoo or on our Facebook Page BiRequest on Facebook.

results.description:
**There are 100 people signed up for the league who are there every night REGARDLESS of who is signed up from Meetup - so don't worry about how many people have RSVP'ed just here on Meetup.  We just leave up the Meetup for any new people (that's you!) who would want to come join us.  There are ALWAYS a ton of people.** 

Who: Exactly 1 buttload of good people
What: FREE Dodgeball!...then bar party with everyone!
Where: Manhattan, Upper East Side, St Joseph School, 420 E 87th St
Why: Fun n stuff
How: read below...

Oh hi there person reading this.  My name's Ari.  You should come play dodgeball with us.  That's a fun game.  Remember that from grade school?  Yeah, apparently when you're an adult you're still allowed to do that.  Who knew?  Oh, and now we get to go to a bar afterward instead of back to math class.  So there's that.  Adulthood has its perks.

See, here's some photos of shenanigans:

Doesn't that look like those people are having good times?  That could be you having good times!  You're a people!  And good times are the best kinds of times.

---

FAQ

SO WHO ARE YOU?
So the deal is that we're the group in NYC that gets together to play dodgeball every week...because we are overgrown children.  Sometimes old school rubber playground balls, sometimes little soft jello ones, sometimes some foam ones.  We're not here to F you.  That's why it's FREE for new folk.    But we're more a community than anything (but how legit does our website look?!) and just a good group of people running around with a childhood sport...and then, you know, a bar after if that's your thing.  

I WANT IN!  BUT WHAT IF I'M BAD/SCARED?
We don't just throw you to wolves - we'll introduce you around, explain everything, and no experience or athleticism necessary!  No one's gonna bully you or not want to play/hang out with you for being "bad" - no one cares about that...that's what a dick would do.  And we're not dicks.


WHAT IF I'M LATE?
It's just dodgeball, relax.  Come and go as you please.  The earlier you get there, the more you play of course, but no worries.

WHAT ABOUT MY STUFF? WHAT DO I WEAR?
There are bathrooms to change in if you need to.  Everyone leaves their stuff by the side of the court.  Plenty come straight from work.  Whatever you'd want to run around in is cool for clothes.  You wanna come in your work suit?  Rock on.

THIS IS AWESOME.  IS THERE A LEAGUE?!  I WANT MORE!

There is a full league that goes on too, if you're interested.  Same deal - good or bad all welcome!  More formal with teams and schedules and trophies and costume themes and karaoke and drink deals and all... More info here: www.sandlotsportsnyc.com/register , but any questions just lemme know!

Any questions, don't hesitate!  We'll get back to you! 

facebook.com/groups/NYCDodgeball

results.description:
What is Innovation Weekend New York?

Innovation Weekend New York is a pitch contest for early stage New York based startups looking to expand internationally. It is the first stop on Innovation Weekend's 2016 world tour which will visit Berlin, London, Osaka, Tokyo and possibly a few other cities before returning to Tokyo at years end for 2016's Grand Finale event.

During each stop on this year's world tour, two start ups will be invited to Tokyo to participate in the Innovation Weekend Grand Finale for 2016. During the Grand Finale event they will learn about the startup ecosystem in Japan and meet Japanese investors and companies that can assist them with global expansion.

Why should I attend the event?

Innovation Weekend New York is an night of inspiration and celebration for New York's leading entrepreneurs. New York currently has one of the world's most exciting startup communities and through Innovation Weekend New York attendees will get the chance to hear first hand how some of the leading startups in the area plan to globally scale their businesses.

Innovation Weekend New York will also touch upon its Japanese roots through a keynote address by its founder, Ikuo Hiraishi, who will provide an overview on the current startup ecosystem in Japan.

Additionally, Innovation Weekend New York will be a great networking opportunity for entrepreneurs looking to learn more about the Japanese market. Ikuo and other members of SunBridge Global Ventures will be in attendance to meet members of New York's startup community.

Innovation Weekend New York will be hosted by WeWork Chelsea, and this will provide a chance for attendees view the WeWork space and learn more about the great work they do to support entrepreneurs and startups who use their workspaces everyday.

Why should I pitch? ( Apply to pitch here - http://innovation-weekend.jp/iwny#iwnyapply)

The winner and runner-up of Innovation Weekend New York will be invited and flown to Tokyo to attend the Grand Finale at the end of 2016. The startups at the 2015 Grand Finale received great international exposure and some were able to secure funding as a direct result of being part of Innovation Weekend. Others were able to establish strong business relationships during the trip and received sponsored trips back to Japan to speak about entrepreneurship and further build their business relationships in Japan.

Details

Date: April 21st(Thur), 2016

Venue: WeWork Chelsea, 115 W 18th street, New York, NY 10011

Charge: Free!

Timetable:

6:00pm Doors open
6:30pm Opening remarks by Ikuo Hiraishi, co-founder of SunBridge Global Ventures
7:00pm Guest speakers - TBD
7:30pm Break
7:45pm Innovation Weekend Live (Startup Pitches!)
9:00pm - 10:00pm Reception party and announcement of the winners

Please make sure to fill in your first name and last name, otherwise you may not enter the building!

results.description:
Thursday evening, April 21, 2016

EVENING DETAILS:

6:00PM - Doors open, head to the Radio City room on the 6th floor.

6:15PM - Introduction by the host, housekeeping, sponsors,

6:30PM - Main presentation begins (see abstract below).

Your RSVP is required to add your name to the building security guest list. Please keep your RSVP up-to-date should you find yourself unable to come.


No Schema, No Problem! – Introduction to Azure DocumentDB

Abstract

This session presents an overview of Azure DocumentDB, a new massively-scalable, fully managed NoSQL database platform designed specifically for modern web and mobile applications. Like other NoSQL platforms, DocumentDB supports a schema-free data model and scales easily. But it also offers several unique features that make it a compelling candidate for NoSQL scenarios.

We begin by explaining NoSQL and document databases, and how they compare with traditional relational database platforms. Then we tour the many features of DocumentDB, including rich querying with SQL (that’s right, you query this NoSQL database using SQL!), and client development using the REST API and the DocumentDB SDKs. Next, learn about the server-side programming model and write fully transactional stored procedures, triggers, and user-defined functions. Also explore tunable consistency, scale-out partitioning, custom indexing, attachments, and more. Attend this session, and get up to speed on DocumentDB today!

Goals

Get introduced to NoSQL, document databases, and Microsoft Azure DocumentDB.

Understand the differences between NoSQL and relational database platforms, and when to choose one or the other for your next application.

Learn about the unique NoSQL features of DocumentDB, including rich query over schema-free data, client development, server-side programming, tunable consistency, indexing, partitioning, and attachments.

About Lenni Lobel:

Leonard Lobel (Microsoft MVP, SQL Server) is the chief technology officer and co-founder of Sleek Technologies, Inc., a New York-based development shop with an early adopter philosophy toward new technologies. He is also a principal consultant at Tallan, Inc., a Microsoft National Systems Integrator and Gold Competency Partner.

Programming since 1979, Lenni specializes in Microsoft-based solutions, with experience that spans a variety of business domains, including publishing, financial, wholesale/retail, health care, and e-commerce. Lenni has served as chief architect and lead developer for various organizations, ranging from small shops to high-profile clients. He is also a consultant, trainer, and frequent speaker at local usergroup meetings, VSLive, SQL PASS, and other industry conferences. Lenni has also authored several SQL Server books and online courses.
results.name: No Schema, No Problem! – Introduction to Azure DocumentDB (Lenni Lobel)

Presentation 1: AEM 6.2 Sneak Preview by Sethu Iyer, Principal Architect - Partner and Alliances at Adobe (Digital Marketing)


Speaker Bio: Sethu Iyer is the Principal Architect, Partner and Alliances for Adobe. A veteran of the content management space, Sethu has been with Adobe since 2012 and is responsible for pre-sales solutions engineering with Adobe’s Partner Ecosystem.

Presentation 2: AEM - eCommerce Integration Patterns 

Description: This presentation explores the Integration Patterns for AEM – eCommerce integration, which could be applied to integrate AEM (or similar WCMs) with various eCommerce systems based on factors like business requirements, functionality, platform evolution and Integration Architecture. The session covers all aspects of Application Architecture along with an Evaluation Matrix to help anyone to use this approach as a template to choose the right Solution Architecture for their respective  Platform Integration scenarios.

Just 1 Week Left!

Our sister meetup group BTP is hosting a Cybersecurity Panel.

BDPA, Black Technology Professionals, One Hundred Black Men, Inc, Technology Committee and Sirius XM present Cybersecurity: Ask The Experts

Technology is driving business at an unprecedented speed. But, on an almost daily business, cyber security breaches or hacks are taking place throughout the world. So, how do you protect your business, your family, your self? Join our distinguished panel of seasoned cybersecurity experts as they discuss cybersecurity in the real world and how it affects us personally and professionally. Light food and refreshments will be served.

Our Panelists:

Michael Dunner 
Senior Technical Account Manager 
Microsoft Corporation 

Michael has close to 20 years IT experience in the areas of software development, program management, project management, consulting, and service delivery management. He has worked at Microsoft for over 16 years and the majority of his experience has been in the area of cyber security, where he served as a Program Manager in both Window Security and Office Trustworthy Computing and as a Cyber Security Consultant. He has co-authored  two best-selling titles on writing secure code and holds degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration.

Anthony Dupree 
CIO and Chief Information Security Officer 
Novitex Enterprise Solutions


Prior to joining Novitex, Anthony served as the Senior Director of Technical Security Standards and Risk Assessment at McGraw-Hill Education, where he oversaw information security programs. He also held executive roles at Elizabeth Arden and Toys R Us, managing global enterprise IT security, network infrastructure and risk and compliance programs.

Anthony has served as an Army Reserve officer for over 25 years achieving the rank of Lieutenant Colonel; received the Bronze star for outstanding achievement while deployed during Operation Iraqi Freedom in 2003. 

Anthony holds certifications from the Information Systems Audit and Control Association and the International Council of E-Commerce Consultants. He received his Bachelor of Arts degree from the New York Institute of Technology and a Master's degree in Technology from the Stevens Institute of Technology. 

Anthony Dupree was recently recognized as a 2016 Silver Winner of the Info Security Products Guide Global Excellence Award for CSO/Security Executive of the Year! More than 50 judges from a broad spectrum of industry voices from around the world participated in these awards, and winners were honored for their excellence in every facet of the industry including products, people behind the successes and best companies.

Omar McKenzie 
Chief Information Security Officer 
Gravitas

Omar has been a technology professional for over 15 years including 10 years designing, implementing and streamlining information security protection and assurance solutions in the financial services industry. He is experienced in managing programs for cyber security, information security, audit, and compliance with diverse requirements. Omar has a Master’s degree in Information Security from Nova Southeastern University and is also a Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) since 2003 and a Certified Information System Security Architecture Professional (ISSAP) since 2005.  Omar is also a member of the Cloud Security Alliance. 

Other Panelists TBA:

Moderator:

Tyrone T. McKinney is a technology industry veteran with over two decades of experience working for some of the largest Fortune 100 companies. He has extensive experience in many technical arenas including but not limited to enterprise architecture, backup and recovery, business continuity planning, contingency planning, disaster recovery, infrastructure design and deployment, and systems architecture and support.

Tyrone  has worked as a Senior Technology Consultant for Actavis, AT&T Information Systems, AT&T Corporate Headquarters, Bank of America, CitiGroup/Salomon Smith Barney, Bloomberg LP, Credit Agricole, CBS, CBTS, CS First Boston, Collective Systems, Federal Reserve Bank of NY, JPMorgan Chase & Co., Markit, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, UBS Inc., Xaxis and XL Capital Group. He studied at St. John's University where he successfully completed course work for an undergraduate degree in computer science and he has completed numerous technical courses and seminars over the last twenty years.

Tyrone holds technical certifications from Brainbench, RedHat, Sun Microsystems, and Veritas Software. He has been or is a member of AITP, ASNP, IWA-HWG, International Who's Who of Professionals, Madison Who's Who and USENIX. Tyrone is a Board member and Technology Chair of 100 Black Men Inc., of New York, meetup group organizer of the Black Technology Professionals and Minority Technology Careers and is also the President of BDPA Metro New York[masked]

Light food and refreshments will be served. 

Thursday April 21, 2016 
6:00 P.M. - 9:00 P.M. 
Sirius - XM Broadcast Headquarters 
1290 Avenue of the Americas , 11th Floor 
New York, NY 10020

Attendees MUST RSVP by April 19, 2016.

results.description:
Join us for our Digital Camera Workshop! There are a few spaces left so be quick! Seminar Digital Camera: Thursday Apr 21, 6:00-8:00 PM.


Each settings on your camera provides a world of potential for bettering your images. Whether you use a DSLR or a point and shoot, there are tons of tricks that you may be missing out on. We'll explore settings such as exposure compensation and various presets that can turn a regular image into a special one. Our knowledgeable instructors will guide you through all the main options that your camera has, and how and when to apply each of them based on the effect and scene that you are looking to portray.


Additionally, this class will thoroughly introduce to all other digital photography related topics that you will need to know when making your next camera purchase. These subjects include, megapixels, lenses, noise, white balance, ISO, SD cards and much more. Never miss that shot again! Join us and learn to maximize your camera's potential to match with your creative skills. Requirements: Digital camera (SLR or Point and shoot). No prior knowledge required.

Everyone is welcome!

results.description:
Graybar Toastmasters is open to all who wish to improve their public speaking and leadership skills. In addition, this is a great way to network with a dynamic and diverse group of professionals.

Founded in 1954, we are one of the oldest Toastmasters clubs in New York City. We are a friendly club with members dedicated to helping each other become better speakers.

We meet from 6:15pm to 8:15pm on the 1st and 3rd Thursdays of each month in the same location. 

Our meetings are structured to allow everbody participate, practice and learn.

In our meetings the members of the club take different roles that allow them to practice and improve their public speaking and leadership skills by completing different projects.

The different roles include giving prepared presentations, chairing the meeting, improvising a short speech, telling a joke, giving feedback to speakers, evaluating the whole meeting, among others, all in a very friendly and supportive environment.

People who RSVP this meetup attend as guests. They introduce themselves at the beginning of the meeting and give feedback at the end, and some of them may participate in an improv exercise, this is an opportunity for you to check out the club coming to one or a couple of meetings, and decide if you want to join as an active member.


To learn more about Toastmasters International please visit http://www.toastmasters.org/

See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: 28 East 35th Street, between Park and Madison in New York City. To enter, please press buzzer #2 outside the red door for the Gallery/Lounge on the 1st Floor. PLEASE attend the meeting only if you RSVP since the space available is limited.

results.description:
Come and meet our community of local real estate investors, build your network, and learn why real estate is IDEAL and why you should be involved with our community of real estate investors. We constantly learn & earn together and have fun together. Within our real estate investing community, we train people with no experience to people who have been working in the real estate field for many years. So it's not important what experience you have! Working with our community, you will learn in depth knowledge of how real estate investing strategies work and you will also develop yourself to be a successful real estate entrepreneur.

At this meeting we talk about the biggest money making opportunities (Wholesaling, Fix and Flips, Buy & Holds, Seller Financed Notes + Tax Liens/Deeds, Multi-Family/Commercial and Money Lending) for a Real Estate Investor in today’s market. You will get to learn about new investors that are investing in real estate and making $10,000-$100,000+ per real estate transaction, we will also talk about how you can make $1,000-$10,000 commissions helping our community grow and you will learn working strategies from professional and practicing Real Estate Investors on how to create wealth through real estate investing.. This way you can learn & earn, get educated so you can invest in real estate, enjoy your life and pass your wealth on to future generations. Because we will cover a LOT of things in a short amount of time such as saving money on taxes, investment opportunities and other ways to make money working with our team, only those who attend the orientation will get invited to private follow up meetings to cover more in depth advanced strategies and working with our community.

To attend, simply RSVP & answer the registration questions for location! If you would like to bring a friend or business partner with you to the meeting, please email us their name, email address and phone number so that we can make sure they are registered for the meeting.

results.description:
LIMIT: 50 people

BRAND NEW Meetup! You might have heard about this, but were skeptical that it was even truly possible. Well, not only is it possible, but there are many people doing exactly this throughout the state of New Jersey, and neighboring New York and Pennsylvania as well. That's right, you can make some extra money fairly quickly in Real Estate and you can do it during the weekends and without a real estate license. How? This meetup we will discuss all the options.

Real Estate is on the rise again and there has never been a better time to get in. Housing prices are currently at the bottom of the curve and starting to rise. The buying season is quickly approaching so there are going to be PLENTY of opportunities for people to make some extra money fairly easily and rather quickly.

The leader of this meetup quit his full-time job to start using the techniques that he will share with you on April 21. Here is what you will learn:

- How he made $16,000 on his very first deal without using any of his own money or credit.
- How he consistently finds deals like this that have brought him a steady flow of income.
- What the specific techniques he uses that require no money and no credit.
- Other techniques that also work well with minimal cost.
- Why there will never be a shortage of these deals
- How to use the money you make to create a brand new life for yourself and your family, using real estate as an investment tool.
- How to build your wealth using real estate while securing a future income.

This meetup will be limited to only 50 people. You MUST register to attend this meetup.
results.name: Make Money In Real Estate Part Time - No Credit, No Cash, No License, NO PROBLEM

This is an opportunity to practice Japanese conversation, and discuss and study the grammar, particles, Kanji, and culture. The topic varies among all these, according to what people are interested in talking about and the natural flow of conversation.

Members of all levels are welcome, from absolute beginners on up, and there is never a prerequisite. Native speakers are also encouraged to attend, both to lend their expertise and to receive the benefit of a look at the structure of Japanese from an outside linguistic perspective.

Here's a photo of the area where we meet, for reference:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The meeting is free, with no membership dues, hourly costs, or other expenses.

results.description:
Join our Earth Month Third Thursday celebration!

This special edition of our Third Thursday Workshop brings together zero waste expert Jacquie Ottman with Treasures in the Trash creator Nelson Molina, curator Robin Nagle and filmmaker Kelly Adams.

Jacquie Ottman, founder of WeHatetoWaste.com will present key principals and every day tips of achieving zero waste. A pioneer in green marketing, award-winning author, and passionate zero waste advocate. Ottman is on a mission to accelerate NYC's “Zero Waste" goal of achieving a 90% reduction in solid waste by 2030, by working with communities to help foster a positive shift in consumption culture.

Following the zero waste presentation will be a special screening of “One Man’s Trash” the award winning short film documentary by filmmaker Kelly Adams which follows now-retired DSNY sanitation worker Nelson Molina and his 30 year collection of found objects.

The workshop will conclude with a Q & A segment with Nelson Molina and museum curator Robin Nagle to discuss the curatorial approach to collecting, the storage process and most intriguing discovery of materials found during his 30 years as a DSNY sanitation worker.

Refreshments generously provided by Ninkasi Brewing Company

Free admission made possible by the Shelley & Donald Rubin Foundation and Friends of MFTA
results.name: Third Thursday: Earth Month Celebration

• Will I learn enough at MakerSquare to have a career as a software engineer?

• What are hiring managers looking for in prospective candidates?

• How does MakerSquare's hiring network work?

• How does MakerSquare prepares students for the hiring process? 

For those who will be joining us for the first time in this series, we welcome questions about MakerSquare's JavaScript curriculum, and anything else you may want to know about us! Please RSVP to let us know you're coming – we're looking forward to meeting you and answering all of your questions!
results.name: Dinner Q&A with MakerSquare Founders and Execs

Game description: 

Teams are 4 V 4, no goalies, no gender requirements (but we'd like at least 1 female player per team). Games will be played on a 1st goal rotation basis or 15 minutes time limit. The team that scores first stays on  the field. But if your team remains on the field after scoring 3 goals, we'll split the team up so that everyone has a fair chance to have a great game.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! 

VERY IMPORTANT: 

- NO FOULS

- NO SIDE TACKLING

- NO PUSHING

- NO TELLING OFF

* ZERO TOLERANCE*


By minimizing physical contact, we minimize injuries and violence.


         “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!

We encourage competitive, but safe play. 

We reserve the right to ask anyone to leave who has exhibited any behavior that could be construed as violent, offensive, or dangerous. 

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game. 


Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board, 10 PM the night before to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

A positive attitude, pair of sneakers or INDOOR shoes (ONLY), shin guards (recommended) and lots of water.

The Wesak Festival, celebrated at the #Taurus Full Moon, is said to be the day of greatest spiritual opportunity in the year. For Buddhists Wesak marks the birth, enlightenment and death of the Buddha. In the ageless wisdom it is a living event, a time when a great blessing is poured forth upon the world by the Buddha. This blessing results in an unusual inflow of life and spiritual stimulation, vitalizing the aspiration of all people of goodwill everywhere. 

#Wesak is the highpoint of the spiritual year. Legend speaks of a sacred ceremony in which the Buddha, the Christ and enlightened Beings at the heart of all faiths deliver a special blessing to the world. As we link with this event, a great channel of light is created that uplifts all life.

Thursday April 21 – 6.30 – 7.30 PM EDT

Talk & Meditation –3 West Club, 3W 51st St (between 5th & 6th Ave), 
New York, New York
or Listen to the Wesak Festival Live Broadcast

#Eventbrite - https://www.eventbrite.com/e/wesak-festival-taurus-full-moon-tickets-24790598347


PLEASE JOIN IN THIS GROUP SERVICE ON BEHALF OF HUMANITY

The exact time of the Wesak Full Moon is April 22, 2016 at 1:25 am EDT

"I call your attention to the fact that at the Wesak Festival the Buddha returns to bless his people everywhere and to convey the message of wisdom, light and love to humanity coming as he does from the very Heart of Deity itself -- the Buddha's annual blessing is the outer evidence and guarantee of inner divine guidance and revelation in this present world cycle. Year by year he returns. for a brief minute he reminds us that God exists and ever loves; that he is not unmindful of his people; that the heart of the universe is unalterable compassion and that humanity is not alone." - Alice A. Bailey

results.description:
Contact:   Mike Clancy  [masked]

The actual full moon isn't until the next night but it'll be close!!

Trail info- We will be taking the steps from the Gateway park to the Red trail. The trail is 6 or 7 switchbacks up to the old casino with a very rewarding lookout point where you have sweeping views of the Hudson river and surrounding area. From there, we will head one more mile to the fire tower for even better views!!. We'll probably return by same route but there are also other trails we could take. 


Distance:: 4 miles round trip

Elevation gain:  1,300 feet

Gear: Headlamp/light, water, snack/dinner.

The First 0.8 miles of this hike is hard, and very steep with 1000ft. elevation gain.
Mount Beacon is the second highest point in the Hudson Highlands. Depending on the map, it may be called Mount Beacon or Beacon Mountain. The mountain consists of two peaks. The northern peak is 1531ft and has a series of radio antennas on its summit. The higher southern peak is 1610ft and has a lookout tower on its summit.
On a clear morning we will see the NYC skyline lights from the summit as well as views of the town of Beacon and the majority of the Highlands (including Storm King, Breakneck Ridge, and little Sugarloaf).

                                                     *************

results.description:
In this hands-on session, we'll improve our craft by working on a classic code kata: the bank.

This exercise is great for programmers of all levels. All you need is a laptop with your usual development setup.

We will be practicing TDD and pair-programming. Those who feel up for the challenge can try following the Object Calisthenics rules explained below.

Bank Kata Requirements:

Think of your personal bank account experience!

• Deposit and Withdrawal
• Transfer
• Account statement (date, amount, balance)
• Statement printing
• Statement filters (just deposits, withdrawal, date)

Object Calisthenics Rules:

•  One level of indentation per method
•  Don’t use the ELSE keyword
•  Wrap all primitives and Strings
•  First class collections
•  One dot per line
•  Don’t abbreviate
•  Keep all entities small (50 lines)
•  No classes with more than two instance variables
•  No getters/setters/properties
results.name: Hands-on Session: Bank Kata

Join us for an evening of food, drinks and a few short talks about experimenting with the design process.
We'll hear talks from four designers, each lasting 10-15 minutes. Stick around for an open Q&A at the end!
---

Caylee Betts (Product Designer, DigitalOcean) will give an introduction, including her experience joining a new product vertical at DigitalOcean, and how the team is trying new things while defining their process.


Francisco Hui (Product Designer, Pivotal Labs) will speak about increasing productivity and focus, sharing knowledge, and decreasing feedback time with pair designing (like pair programming!), and how to try it with your team.


Earl Carlson (Product Designer, DigitalOcean) will demonstrate how to learn about your users' hopes, dreams, and fears with reaction gifs.


Adam Meisel (Product Designer, Justworks) will show us how his team tested the Google Ventures week-long design sprint at Justworks, and what they learned (and changed) along the way


---
Whether you're a developer interested in learning more about design, or a designer itching to try new practices in your job, all are welcome.


*Note: You must have an RSVP and a valid ID due to security at the venue*

Please read our meetup's Code of Conduct before attending.

Please sign up for the class via Eventbrite. 

Join us for an introductory dive into Ruby, a beginner-friendly language used on servers in backend web development (i.e., the stuff that goes on between entering a URL and getting a web page back). 

In this workshop, we will walk you through the basics of the Ruby language and how to use it to set up a basic web server. 

Key Takeaways:

• All the tools you need to get up, running and coding with Ruby 

• Ruby syntax for basic programming concepts like variables, loops, methods, strings, arrays and hashes 

• The basics of how the World Wide Web works under the hood 

• Setting up a simple web server and sending HTML pages to a browser 

• Using your server to interact with Twitter via its API 


Prerequisites and Preparation: 

• Please bring your own laptop (Mac, PC or Chromebook). 

•   Please download and install Sublime Text (Hint: the download button is on the home page). 

Light snacks will be provided. 

 
*This event is open to adult (18+) beginners and is an introduction to concepts covered more deeply in the immersive program.

Welcome to TEAM Referral Network, where we are passionate about networking and connecting you with the right professionals to grow your business. TEAM Referral Network includes weekly meetings with your chapter, training programs, business development, and most importantly, quality business relationships.

HOW IT WORKS:

Membership is exclusive. Only one business for each category is allowed to join a TEAM Referral chapter. Weekly meetings give TEAM members the opportunity to market their business and get to know their fellow professionals and the business they represent. 

Members work together for a common goal: to increase their sales income and bottom line. 

WHY IT WORKS:

Everyone appreciates referrals! When people are looking for a product or service, a personal referral beats the Yellow Pages every time. Your business gains the competitive edge when a TEAM member refers someone to you and speaks well of your integrity, quality products and excellent service. If you do the same for your fellow TEAM members, everybody WINS!

There is so much more to TEAM Referral Network that happens outside of our chapter meetings. Members are encouraged to meet one-on-one with other members to get to know each other on a deeper level. The entire TEAM Referral Network has access to all members with the exclusive TEAM-sponsored member’s website. These “mini” websites give added value to your brand’s online presence and search engine rankings (SEO), as well as make it even easier for prospects to find your company online. TEAM Referral Network also provides regular business development trainings. TEAM Referral Network helps you exponentially expand your sphere of influence and grow your business referrals.

Come learn how to start or join a chapter!

Surprise! We have an event coming up this Thursday that's come together quickly, but we think you'll love it.


For our seventh event, we'll be at the lovely space run by Spark Labs near Union Square.

As always, we'll have a fantastic panel on hand. Joining us is Kat Vorotova, Cofounder and CEO of Try the World, Loïc Moisand, Cofounder and CEO of Synthesio, and Kerry Flynn from the International Business Times.

We'll be talking about how startups should approach the press when expanding to new countries, along with how journalists view and evaluate foreign startups. 

This event is in partnership with the La French Touch Conference, an event that aims to bridge the French and U.S. entrepreneurial ecosystems.

I'll be moderating, since I went to Paris once.

As always, we'll follow this rough schedule:

6:30 - Arrive and talk to each other

7:00 - Panel discussion  

8:00 - More talking to each other  

8:30ish - Leave

And since it's such short notice, we've decided to waive the entry fees for this event. But we'll still have some nice food and beer for everyone on hand.

Look forward to seeing all of you wonderful people there.

Here’s what we’ve got going on:

• A panel discussion and Q&A with Liz Hall from Trello, Jason Francis from Nomadness Travel Tribe LLC, and Alexandra Sofen from Etsy.

Panelists include: 

• Liz Hall is the VP of People at Trello and handles all matters related to recruiting, retention, performance management, and employee happiness. She has over 11 years of experience scaling companies and creating company culture. She also created the Fog Creek Fellowship in partnership with The Flatiron School to mentor woman graduates and help kickstart their careers in code. To date the program has 50 Fellows total with 100% of job-seekers (47) finding jobs as software engineers. She lives in Astoria, New York with her husband and two children. @Liz_Hall1

• Alexandra “Ali” Sofen is the Forums Programming Manager for the online marketplace, Etsy. She is passionate about Etsy’s mission to connect people from around the world, both online and offline, to make, sell, and buy unique goods. As Forums Programming Manager, she acts as a liaison between Etsy’s online community of 25 million users and staff of over 800 employees. Ali has created and implemented several unique initiatives that brings together the Etsy community of creative entrepreneurs through online engagement and in-person events. Connect with Alexandra on LinkedIn. Ali also recently opened her own Etsy shop making beaded leather wrap bracelets!  

• Jason Francis is the Head of Social Media for Nomadness Travel Tribe LLC. As such he oversees a private digital community of over 12,000 international members. In addition, he manages all the Nomadness social media sites which collectively total over 50,000 followers. He is also a social media consultant, public speaker and content creator. Connect with him on LinkedIn.

Don't forget to RSVP!

Look forward to seeing you there!

The Building Community Team

results.description:
Celebrate Earth Day with the office of Environmental Affairs and Community Green as we proudly present - Love Thy Nature. We are beginning our 7th year of monthly environmental documentaries on Thursday, April 21, 6:30p.m., at the Public Library, 50 So. Fullerton Avenue. All events are free and open to the public.


Love Thy Nature focuses on how we’ve lost touch with nature. This disconnect hurts our health, dulls our spirit, and threatens our future. Narrated by Liam Neeson, Love Thy Nature is a cinematic immersion into the beauty and intimacy of our relationship with the natural world. With mesmerizing artistry and fascinating details, the film explores how nature nourishes us.

Our collective humankind has come to believe that we are separate from nature, causing us to disrupt billions of years of evolution, a mass extinction of species which threatens the survival of the human race. The film shows how connectedness with the natural world is key to ensuring our species’ future, discussing biomimicry and The Biological Revolution in science, medical health, neurological health and emotional stability.

Traversing the globe, Love Thy Nature shares the dazzling spectacles of our planet while revealing how a deeper connection with nature transforms us as people and communities, inspiring us not only to restore our ecosystems, but also our human family, and ourselves. 

Please join us, and bring a friend, a family member, or your neighbor for this fascinating film screening, and an open public discussion afterwards. For further questions, please contact Marnie Vyff at (973)[masked] or [masked]
results.name: Montclair Environmental Movie Night: Love Thy Nature

results.description:
This is a free group for anyone who enjoys playing board games and would like to make new friends while doing so. No previous knowledge of board games is necessary. We're happy to help newcomers along with how to play, as well as how to plan strategies to win the games.  

Our event is every Thursday night at Dave & Buster's in Westbury Long Island from 6:30pm to 10:30pm.  You can leave prior to 10:30pm if you want, also please note that Dave & Buster's closes at Midnight for those who want to stay later. 

Most people arrive at 6:30pm.  We use the first 30 minutes to talk, order food/drinks, and pick out games while we wait for any people that are a little late.  Promptly at 7pm we split into groups and play our games that typically take 2 hours to play.  So, if you arrive after 7pm there is a good chance that you will not be able to get into a game and can watch us play if you'd like.  At the end of the night we play a couple of additional shorter games that you can get into.

This group meets in the Large Dining Room at the table directly in front of the wall with 9 Big Screen TV's (We are located 1 room over from the pool tables).  There is no cover charge to enter Dave & Buster's and plenty of parking is available. Also, there is no fee to join this meetup group. All that management at Dave & Buster's asks is that each person purchase $5 off their menu (it can be 1 appetizer, or 1 dessert, or a few sodas, basically whatever you choose).  

Plenty of board games will be present at this event, but feel free to bring some of your favorites. Some of the games that we play are Kingsburg, Stone Age, Lords of Waterdeep, Istanbul, Ticket to Ride, Carcassonne, Castles of Mad King Ludwig, Love Letter Batman, Splendor, Pirate's Cove, Five Tribes, Castles of Burgundy, and more.  

Here is a list of the board games I own on the BGG website: 

https://boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/MarkNY8?own=1&subtype=boardgame&ff=1

Here is a list of Co-Host Kenny's games on BGG: 

https://boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/kenk1982?own=1&subtype=boardgame&ff=1

Looking forward to meeting you. 

Mark
results.how_to_find_us: This group meets in the Large Dining Room at the table directly in front of the wall with 9 Big Screen TV's.   We are 1 room over from the pool tables.
results.name: Thursday Night Board Games at Dave & Busters!

results.description:
I'm loving the momentum of this group and witnessing how folks are improving their language skills and making friends. To me, it makes all of this worth doing!

So let's get ready for another great meetup! 

As always, first introduce yourself in the language you are studying. Then introduce yourself in your native language. 

Following that, we will dedicate 30 minutes towards helping those learning English, then 30 minutes of Chinese. 

Then we mingle again until its time to go. 

We are usually done by 8:30 but those that want to stick around or continue hanging out after the meetup (bubble tea, karaoke, etc) are more than welcome to do so!

Thanks again for your support thus far and let's have many more great meetups! 非常感谢大家的支持！

This is a FREE yoga class that meets from 6:30 to 8:00 pm, instructed by Chia-Ti Chiu, one of the organizers of this Meetup group.

It is an OPEN LEVEL HATHA FLOW class, appropriate for beginners to advanced students.  There are many variations given to accommodate the different levels of yoga experience.


** You will need to bring your own mat.  There are no yoga mats for rent or use. You can buy yoga mats inexpensively at Marshalls, Filene's Basement, Modells, TJ Maxx, and Target. Many yoga studios also carry a wide range of mats for sale.

IF YOU COME FOR THE FIRST TIME: PLEASE FILL OUT THE REGISTRATION FORM AT THE FRONT DESK. RSVPing on Meetup does not count as Beacon registration.  Your participation and registration helps keep the numbers needed for this program to stay free!


FOR EVERYONE: PLEASE SIGN IN AT THE FRONT DESK CLEARLY AND LEGIBLY

DIRECTIONS:The Beacon Center is located in PS 198. It is an elementary school that takes up the whole block; entrance is on 3rd Ave. The exact address is: 1700 Third Avenue, between 95 & 96 St.

BY SUBWAY: 6 train to 96 St. Walk 1 block East on 96 St to Third Ave. Make a right onto Third Ave.

BY BUS: Third Ave Bus - M101, 102, 103 to 96 St.

Madison Ave Bus - M1, M2,M3, or M4 To 96 St.


ANY QUESTIONS? Contact Chia-Ti through Meetup or through her website: www.onelovewellness.com

results.description:
Maximize your potential with Russian Martial Arts!

CONQUER THE FEAR of a violent encounter.

INCREASE YOUR STRIKING POWER and learn practical self defense methods that will work ANYTIME, ANYWHERE


Develop a STRONG, FLEXIBLE, MOBILE PHYSIQUE and MENTAL FOCUS that will carry over into every aspect of your life.


Learn all this and much, much more at NJ RMA Self Defense Group, the official Meetup Group of System of Combat NJ.  Start your NEW YEAR with with Russian Martial Arts, your first class is FREE.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1tm6NW32NdI


Enjoy your first class for free and after that, it is only $10 per class with discounts available for pre-payment. No contract required! Classes are held at 7:00pm on Tuesday and Thursday evenings at the YMHA OF UNION on 501 Green Lane, Union, NJ 07083.

About Us

If you are interested in Systema, Reality Based Self Defense,  Martial Arts, Grappling, Street Defense, or Mobility and Body Awareness, this is the Meetup Group for you.  Men and women, seasoned martial artists and raw beginners alike will benefit from our dynamic classes which are tailored to the level and needs of the students. We focus on providing comprehensive instruction, plenty of personal attention and a relaxed atmosphere where you can train at your own pace and intensity. Individual classes are fast-paced and varied, ranging in subject from striking mechanics, grappling and ground fighting, evasive movement, weapon defense, sparring, and dealing with multiple attackers to women's self defense and street safety.
Copyright © 2013 System of Combat NJ                                   

About Systema

Systema is a combat style based on ancient Slavic fighting methods which were collected and codified by the Russian Soviet special forces.  It is a devastatingly effective and versatile combative program that can easily stand alone, or augment your existing practice.  The overarching focus is on responding to a threat spontaneously with natural, instinctive movement which strengthens and restores the body, clarifies the mind, and provides a framework for healthy, safe, life-long activity 

About the instructor 

Jim has over 25 years of martial arts experience in various styles including Brazilian Jiu-jitsu (BJJ), Silat, Boxing, Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) and Karate.  He is certified to teach Systema by Alex Wilkie (Alex Wilkie's Martial Arts Academy).

Directions

When you arrive, let the front desk know you are there for the martial arts class and they will direct you. (You do not have to be a Y-member to attend this class).  For general inquiries or more information, message organizers Jimi D or Drew here on the Meetup page.  If you need to reach the instructor, Jim, for any reason, call 

<a>[masked]</a>

-nine-zero-eight-three-zero-three-five-zero-three-one-


Looking forward to training with you!

results.description:
Please RSVP at Eventbrite https://www.eventbrite.com/e/learn-meteor-by-creating-a-chat-app-workshop-tickets-24485896977<a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/intermediate-meteor-workshop-tickets-24485896977"></a>. 

Cost of class:  $40.

Meteor.js is a popular application platform, that allows you to quickly develop reactive apps for iOS, Android, and the web, entirely in Javascript.  We'll spend some time getting everyone up to speed on some basics of Meteor as we build a functional chat application with very little code.

We'll be developing on version 1.3 which is a huge improvement from an end user platform to a more developer friendly programming environment.  Highlights include faster application rebuild times, built-in support for Java Script features, cross-package support and official support for React and Angular as view layer alternatives to Blaze.  This class will focus on the following:  

             • Mobile


             • Modules

             • Testing

Prerequisites:

Absolute beginners welcome.  Laptop required.

About the Instructors:


Adrian Lanning is the author of the Meteor roles package.  Adrian co-organizes the Meteor NY meetups and DevShop NY.  Adrian is the Co-Founder, CTO OnScene Technologies, Inc. https://share911.com/


Aurelia is a developer working on community and code at the Mozilla Science Lab, you might have seen her newsletter emails for Girl Develop It.
results.name: Learn Meteor by Creating a Chat App Workshop

results.description:
Love brazilian music? This workshop is for you!
We'll get to work on classics of bossa-nova, understand the rhythm patterns and learn the finger style technique to master comping and the nuances of brazilian clave.
You'll get familiar with 7th, 9th, 13th, diminish chords.
Nylon string guitar is recommended for this class but you won't get turned away if you bring a steel string guitar.
You must be familiar with open chords and comfortable playing songs and switching chords in time. Barre chord knowledge is a plus but nor required for this workshop.
This is a one hour workshop with the option of performing three songs May 1st at Arlene's Grocery.
Obrigada!

results.description:
For the next meetup, Avi Kivity will be presenting on Seastar.

Abstract:

Writing I/O intensive applications in today's environments, with hundreds of thousands of available SSD IOPS, dozens of cores, end tens of gigabits per second network interfaces, is more challenging than ever. We will present Seastar, a modern, open-source C++14 framework for wring high concurrency, high throughput server applications. Seastar is the framework behind ScyllaDB, a drop-in Apache Cassandra replacement that provides 10X throughput improvements on the same hardware.

Project URL: http://www.seastar-project.org/
Seastar source: https://github.com/scylladb/seastar

Bio:

Avi Kivity, CTO of ScyllaDB, is known mostly for starting the Kernel-based Virtual Machine (KVM) project, the hypervisor underlying many production clouds. He has worked for Qumranet and Red Hat as KVM maintainer until December 2012. Avi is now CTO of ScyllaDB, a company that seeks to bring the same kind of innovation to the NoSQL space.
results.name: Seastar: C++14 framework for High Concurrency, High Throughput Servers

results.description:
Description: Democratic. Bottom-up. Engaging. Lean coffees foster group participation and ensure that the topics that matter most to the most people get discussed. 

But lean coffees only work well up to a certain number of participants. What if your group is too big to run a lean coffee? What if your meeting has a presentation or “sage on the stage” component? What if the session is virtual?

In this presentation, we’ll review a few general principles for capturing the ethos of lean coffee in large, presentation style sessions and introduce a tool that presenters and meeting facilitators can use to connect with their audiences.

Presenter: John Kresse is Brand Manager of Digital Products at W. W. Norton Publishing, where he works with teams to launch and market education technology products. He loves product discovery, seeks new ways to improve personal and team work productivity and satisfaction, and is hooked on Friday morning lean coffees. Originally from Charleston, South Carolina, John is a basketball junkie (he played at Emory) and bookworm. 


Location: Spotify is on 45 W. 18th Street. That's between 6th and 5th avenues, above the Bed Bath and Beyond. They're up on the 7th floor.
results.how_to_find_us: Between 6th and 5th avenues, above the Bed Bath and Beyond. Spotify is up on the 7th floor.
results.name: "Capturing the spirit of Lean Coffee in large meetings" with John Kresse

results.description:
Abstract:

Machine learning has transformed the technology industry over the last
decade, forming the basis for web search, speech recognition, product
recommendations, and self-driving cars. With the increased adoption of
electronic health records and a surge in funding for health IT
startups, health care is undergoing a similar transformation. I will
talk about how machine learning has the potential to change healthcare
across the spectrum, from enabling the next-generation electronic
health record to population-level risk stratification from health
insurance claims (examples will come from my group's work). These
innovations will lead to increased quality of care and decreased cost.

Speaker Bio:

David Sontag is an Assistant Professor at New York University's
Courant Institute and Center for Data Science. His research focuses on
using machine learning to improve health care, including development
of novel algorithms for early detection of Type 2 diabetes, modeling
disease progression, electronic phenotyping, visualization, and
clinical decision support in emergency departments. Prior to joining
NYU, he was a postdoctoral researcher at Microsoft Research New
England. David's research has received recognition including the
Sprowls Award for the best doctoral thesis in Computer Science at MIT,
best paper awards at EMNLP, UAI and NIPS, and the NSF CAREER award.
results.name: How is Machine Learning Going to Change Health Care?
