results.description:
It's that time of the year! Time to get outside and soak in some nice views and vitamin D and enjoy the fresh Spring air.

Let's get off the beaten path and explore one of the less visited areas of the Hudson Highlands - Black Rock Forest.


Black Rock Forest owes its name to the magnetite that was mined in this area in the 18th century. Although this natural preserve is located just across the road from the Storm King Park, it is often overlooked by the people in the hiking community...which means less crowded trails for us!


The Hike:


We'll do a 8-10 miles long loop, depending on trail and weather conditions. There is a network of developed hiking trails and gravel roads inside of the preserve, so we'll have some flexibility in choosing the exact route, but you can expect some steady moderate climbs/descents with some shorter steep sections that may require light rock scrambling. About 3 hours into the hike, we'll take a lunch break, so please bring something to snack on. The entire hike with all breaks, at a decent pace, should not take more than 5-6 hours.

Gear:

Proper footwear is essential - a pair of comfortable, broken-in shoes, with good traction. Please no flip-flops, clogs, skate shoes and similar footwear on this hike. 

Bring enough water for the entire day. There is no potable water source anywhere along this hike, so come with your bottles/hydration packs filed up and ready to go.

You will need a small backpack to carry your food, water, and extra clothing. As I mentioned before, on some portions of this hike you may need to use your hands to climb up rocks, so you need your hands to be free.

The weather in the early spring can be unpredictable, and with a bit of a wind chill at the top of the hills along the way, a sunny day can turn into a cold one - so be ready and dress in layers. Bring an extra layer, a hat,  and rain/wind jacket that can fit into your backpack. A pair of gloves can be helpful on a cold, windy day.

As on any given hike - it is always a good idea to have your own map of the area you are hiking. You can purchase NY/NJ conference's West Hudson trail map pack - and bring map #113 with you, or at least print out this map as a backup:

(http://blackrockforest.org/files/blackrock/content/MapNewLogo-EC.pdf)

Sunblock and insect repellents are good to have handy.

We should be done with this hike long before it gets dark, but it's always a good idea to pack a headlamp/flashlight - for unforeseen circumstances.

Getting there:


We will carpool, and share the cost of gas/tolls. Please use the comment field to offer/ask for a ride. 

Driving Directions 


From NYC, take the Palisades Interstate Parkway to its northern terminus at the Bear Mountain Bridge and then continue north on U.S. 9W for about 10 miles to the parking lot on your left. Other option is to take Rt.4 to Rt.17 to I-87 to exit 17, then follow route 32 to Cornwall, take the southbound U.S. 9W, and arrive at the parking lot on your right, after about 1.7 miles. Or just enter the GPS coordinates into your GPS unit and let it lead you to the parking lot.

GPS Coordinates: [masked], [masked]

DISCLAIMER

results.description:
Let's explore less popular trails in the Catskills! Why would we want to do that? These trails offer interesting views and stunning sections of uncrowded tranquility. Today we visit a firetower, one Catskills 100 peak and two gorgeous ponds!

Starting at the Parking Area by Balsam Lake, 1.75 miles to the Balsam Lake Fire Tower, where there is a stunning 360 degree view of the Catskills. From Balsam Lake we go back 0.25 miles where we came from and hike the ups and downs of the Mill Brook Range. This trail runs in a westerly direction, passing over a view point and a Catskills 100 peak (Mill Brook Ridge) at 3480', just barely missing the coveted 3500 foot mark. 

After 5.9 miles we hit Alder Lake, where my plan is we circle the entire lake in the spirit of redlining. After Alder Lake we cross county road 54 and hike another 3 miles along the Touch-Me-Not trail, which ends at Big Pond.

Stunningly Beautiful Big Pond

The distances are:

• Balsam Lake TH - Balsam Lake Firetower: 1.75mi

• Balsam Lake Firetower - junction with Yellow trail: 0.25mi

• Mill Brook Ridge Trail (Yellow) to Alder Lake: 5.9mi

• Alder Lake Loop + exit from loop: 2.5mi

• Alder Lake Parking Lot - Big Pond: 3.3mi

Total distance is just under 15 miles and vertical is around 3000.

+++
Responsibility of all hikers: (YOU ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR YOU)
Hiking and other events organized by this Group are inherently risky and may result in death or serious physical or emotional injury.

Join these hikes (or other events) only at your own risk. The hike organizer and those connected to this group and this website may not be held responsible for the safety or well-being of anyone or their pets who chooses to join these events. By going with us, you agree to research the trip, and send the organizer or others questions as necessary. On the trail, we all care for each other as friends, not as guides or leaders or agents – if you sign up to come, you agree to take primary responsibility for yourself. There are no “liability waivers” or other written agreements to sign. By signing up you agree not to hold anyone responsible if something goes wrong for any reason.
Hike Preparation
You are solely responsible for researching each event and for selecting and bringing appropriate gear and supplies, including clothing, food and water, to each event. If you have any questions regarding appropriate gear or supplies, please contact the event organizer for the event. You understand that any guidance given by an organizer is done as a courtesy based on the organizer's personal experience and physical capabilities, which may not be the same as yours, and will not hold any organizer liable for guidance provided. You remain responsible for You."
Leave No Trace: Outdoor skills and ethics --- protect our hiking resources. http://www.lnt.org/pr...
results.name: Catskill Redline Series: Balsam Lake to Big Pond via Alder Lake (15 miles)

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
This is a cross post of an MTBNJ group ride posted to mtbnj.com:

http://www.mtbnj.com/forum/threads/mtbnj-group-ride-4-23-hartshorne.39472/


Hello everyone and welcome back! See below for the details of the first open, non-race MTBNJ group ride:

Place: Hartshorne

Address: 255 Locust Ave, Middletown NJ

Date: Saturday, April 23

Time: 9:00 am

Length: About 2 hours

Pace: Beginner-friendly

Lead: @rottin'

Sweep: @Mitch

Talker: @pooriggy

RSVP: On this thread and here:

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/10L1AomFJXCepEtMpGUNYpURoiADbMjPSORnVwTVDIZk/viewform


For those of you who did a group ride last year

This is more of the same. Casual pace meant to encourage people to get out and ride trails they may have never seen or have not seen often enough to feel comfortable going at it alone. 

For those who did not

I encourage any & all people who have a mild interest in checking the park out or meeting people to join. The rides are very social and allow you to see places & meet people you will not if you stay home or go to the gym. We often have 5-10 team members here so this is your chance to get to know those of us on the board better. I did not get a single complaint about the ride series last year. Many who went to 1 came back for more. 

Disclaimer

Mountain biking is a serious sport. If you go off the trails you may be subject to tiger attacks, random meteor showers, poison ivy in the crotch, or you may be subject to a hootenanny. There is some expectation that you can get yourself out alive if you get lost, but the collective group will point you in the right direction or at least throw meat in the general other direction from the tiger if you are so attacked. 

It is a good idea to have the following things in your pack if you need mechanical assistance:

1. @woody

Please bring appropriate food & drink and remember, as it is before Memorial Day it is frowned upon to wear white to these social gatherings. 

Hope to see you there.

results.description:
Event Description:


This is a Day Hike, not a backpacking trip.  I will be bringing 3 or 4 fully loaded backpacking kits representing various gear philosophies from traditional to ultralight.  Participants will have the opportunity to take turns carrying each pack to experience the impact of gear selection on comfort while hiking. We will stop along the hike to demonstrate different types of shelters, cooking systems, and water filtration systems.

****THE 9AM AND NOON EVENTS ARE EXACTLY THE SAME. PLEASE DO NOT SIGN UP FOR BOTH!****

Participants are encouraged to bring equipment that they have questions about, but shouldn't feel like they need to go out and purchase gear.  Our objective is to see and try out gear in the field before you make expensive investments.

This is the first part in a series of Intro to Backpacking events which will hopefully culminate in a section hike along the Appalachian Trail. 


Suggested Reading:

Ray Jardin's "Trail Life"

Ryan Jordan's "Lightweight Backpacking & Camping"

Andrew Skurka's "The Ultimate Hiker's Gear Guide"

Section Hiker's Backpacking Blog

CampingJay

Syllabus

Hike Description:

Distance: ~7 Miles

Hiking Time: 6 to 8 hours, including stops.

Attractions: Two scenic lakes, panoramic views, Bald Rocks

Highest Elevation: 1,380

Elevation Gain: ~2,500 feet

Parking Coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Map: NYNJTC Harriman Bear Mountain Trails - Map #118 & 199

Route Description:

Long Path (Aqua) to Dunning (Yellow) to Ramapo-Dunderberg (Red) to Bald Rocks Shelter. Then, Ramapo-Dunderberg (Red) to Long Path (Aqua) to Dunning (Yellow) to Arden Surebridge (Red Triangle)

Recommended Day Hiking Gear:

The 10 Essentials

CampingJay's Gear List


NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear. Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
Just putting this on the calendar in a recurring fashion to allow for people to plan ahead and see if we can make more people intersect.

These will be mostly (unless highlighted) in Watching Reservation, but may occasionally detour to Loantaka, Washington Park, South Mountain and so one. 

In every case, the idea will be to be at that location at 9:30, and to be done at the very last at 10:30. Carpooling may be organized in some cases (via the FB group for efficiency). The trail will be decided when we leave. Whatever strikes our fancy, take a look at past meetups to get a sense. No runner left behind as I will be at back panting heavily anyway. 

If you're wondering wether you're up for a 1 hour run - let us know and we can shorten it or make sure we set our pace adequately. The idea is to enjoy ourselves and nature, not to set any speed records.

Note that this is a member-run meetup: no one is responsible for you but you. Your event host is not responsible for you or any injuries that could happen as you willingly run across rough terrain with roots, rocks, gullies, etc. Don't expect anyone to have first aid knowledge, supplies, or water for you. Just a bunch of like-minded people enjoying the trails together! For more details see section 6.2 of http://www.meetup.com/terms/

-Please do not reserve unless you are 100% sure you can make it. 

- If you were bringing a friend or partner, make sure he or she join HVH because of the liability waver.

(There is a store before the TAKE OFF  to buy snacks water etc...)


9:30am - We will need to drop off our Kayaks in Calliccon  and drive for 15 minutes to Norrowsburg most of the cars and drive back  with a couple of cars (We will make the members who are renting to drive us back) for another 15 minutes to Callicoon to start our Adventure at 10:15am for 2 hours follow by a lunch break…. then another 2 hours to the finish line.

(It will be nice kayaking for about 15 miles slow pace and there will be only one small rapid level 2 at skinner falls to be familiar with rapids so that you can join us for the next series that has more rapids than this trip)

                   (There is also  a local supper & Liquor market store on the way to my place to pick anything you may may need for the night etc...)

4 - 5 pm back to my place for camp, Bonfire & Potluck

Breakfast then take off for your next HVH adventure!

Thank you and looking forward to have fun with you all.

results.description:
P90X LIVE!
Saturday April 23 at 930am at Clove Lakes Park. We meet in the grassy area in front of the white building by the playground on Clove by Victory. 

The short story; 1 hour kick ass workout using light weights(we provide) and body weight(you provide).

Workouts are for all fitness levels whether you’re just starting out and this is your very first workout or if you’ve been pushing hard for years. You will sweat, you will work, you... will HATE IT, but YOU’LL LOVE IT!

The workout is approximately one hour long with breaks. Each participant should bring water and a towel. Optional accessories for the workout include a yoga mat and light dumbbells if you have them. We will have some extra equipment on hand but please bring what you have.

It’s a total body workout beginning with cardio, then moving into lower body strength training, then upper body strength training then lastly ending with a core workout all while moving to the beat of some kick ass music!!

So please, come on out and get your sweat on! And spread the word!

PAGE SHARES ARE VERY MUCH APPRECIATED TO HELP SPREAD THE WORD!

results.description:
LEADER: Peter Reiner ([masked] or[masked]) 

RATING: B 5.5 C+

Meet at 9:30 AM Buttermilk Falls Park off Greenbush Rd. in West Nyack for a car shuttle to the hike starting at Nike Overlook Park. Hike along the Long Path through three parks and, if there’s been some recent rain, views of Buttermilk Falls. Please register for hike. TC Hudson Palisades map 119.

Note that this hike is part of a larger group, the NJR ADK. Most hikers sign up via our printed schedule (see below) and not through Meetup, so though the number of attendees may appear small, we generally have a group of 10-20 on any given hike.

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance: Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

Our Mission: Play safe, get your workout on & HAVE FUN!!

The Lowdown:

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Once wasn't enough! We just barely scratched the surface of this park. Everyone who attended wants to go back to finish our walk.

The 23-mile Bronx River winds down through southern Westchester County and the Bronx creating a peaceful corridor of green.

The park itself is a 718 acre park with baseball fields, playgrounds, woodlands, waterfalls, the NY Botanical Garden and the Bronx Zoo. Bronx River Park, is a linear park that can be explored in sections and actually extends from 233rd Street to the south Bronx where it empties in the Long Island Sound near Hunts Point.

Between Gun Hill Road and Allerton Ave/ Mosholu Parkway the park straddles both sides of the river. It provides photographic interest along its trails.  Come on out and explore this under recognized area of the NYC Park system.

This tour will start at Burke Ave and extend south where more photographic treasures await. Come join us!


Disclaimer: Participation in these events requires that you assume all risks associated with these activities, and that the Organizers, Co-Organizers and Event Hosts are in no way liable for any loss or injury as a result of your participation. In other words, you are attending these events at your own risk!!

P.S. Remember to format your cards, charge your batteries and come with your enthusiasm to make new friends!

results.description: Following in the footsteps of Alfred Kazin, we will explore the streets he describes so vividly in his classic memoir of growing up in the 1930s, A Walker in the City.   We will visit the sites of old Brownsville synagogues, theaters, markets, schools, socialist meeting places, and the Carnegie libraries where Kazin first found his doorway into the world “Beyond!” his teeming tenement neighborhood; our walk will also take us to Highland Park and the “American” neighborhood on the other side of the railroad tracks (Ocean Hill) where Kazin discovered the genteel life he dreamed of.  At each stop, we will read passages from A Walker in the City.   Moderate pace, 5 – 7 miles, plenty of drop-off points.  Bring water and lunch for a picnic in Highland Park. Call or email leader, Joyce Zonana, [masked][masked] for meeting-place and time.  Nonmembers:  $3.

• The MTA on Saturday and Sunday are unpredictable due to Construction. Please give yourself more time to plan ahead.

DESCRIPTION:


A cherry blossom is the flower of any of several trees of genus Prunus, particularly the Japanese cherry, Prunus serrulata, which is called sakura after the Japanese (桜 or 櫻; さくら).

Cherry blossom is speculated to be native to the Himalayas.Currently it is widely distributed, especially in the temperate zone of the Northern Hemisphere including Europe, West Siberia, India, China, Korea, Japan, Canada, and the United States.

Many of the varieties that have been cultivated for ornamental use do not produce fruit. Edible cherries generally come from cultivars of the related species Prunus avium and Prunus cerasus. Cherry blossom are also closely related to other Prunus trees such as the almond, peach, plum and apricot and more distantly to apples, pears and roses.

• Cherry Blossom

results.description:
25k (15.5) miles on the infamous Greenbelt Trail!

Trail Details: Run from Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island to Plainview, Long island and back 7.75 miles each way. This trail varies from mild flats to technical hills and roots. Just because this is Long Island, don't assume that this trail is flat. This is an excellent way to train for next week's Bear Mountain race.

Where: Meet at the Cold Spring Harbor LIRR Train Station.

Via public transit: Take the 8:51 am Long Island Rail Road from Penn Station to Cold Spring Harbor. Travel time 58 minutes. (Alternatively, you can take the LIRR from any station as long as you arrive on the 9:49 train.)


If you are driving: Put 564 Woodbury Rd, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724 in your GPS.

Bag Drop/Etc: There is always a bush or a pile of leaves to stash your stuff in, just make sure everything important is on you while you run. Sometimes BTR members who own cars show up at this location.

As always, we encourage all speeds to join, no matter how fast or slow. This is about running trails and having fun! If you can’t run 15 miles and can only run 7, no worries! This trail is an "up and back", so you can just turn around.

results.description:
Studying for the application process at Fullstack Academy or Grace Hopper Academy? Join the workshop that takes you through the coding assessment step-by-step. We'll review the challenges and run through practice problems, answering questions along the way. 

At the end of the session, you'll feel more confident in your skills and be ready to take the next step towards becoming a developer. 

Get a better sense for the application requirements on the Admissions Prep Materials page.

Workshop Agenda

1. Welcome from Instructors

2. Test-taking strategies: tips on how to ace the admissions coding assessment

3. Coding Challenges: attendees will pair up to solve the 5+ problems in 20 minute blocks

4. Each problem will be followed by a 10 minute review to address the solution

5. Attendees will leave the workshop having completed several coding challenges and receive Review Videos

Reminders

• Bring a computer!

• Workshop begins at 10am on Saturday

• We aren't providing a lunch break, so bring snacks to tide you over!

• Please arrive on time to maximize the effectiveness of the workshop

If you are a beginner, we recommend you complete as many of the following units 1, 2, 3, 5 and 6 of Codecademy's JavaScript track as possible before Saturday.

Grace Hopper Academy is the world’s first immersive coding school for women where students only pay tuition after securing a job. Our mission is to close the gender gap in technology through high-quality education, mentorship, and need-blind admissions. With a proven curriculum and educational program leveraged from partner school Fullstack Academy, Grace Hopper Academy offers an open environment for women to learn software development and become professional engineers.
results.name: Fullstack Academy and Grace Hopper Academy Admissions Prep Workshop

results.description:
Bring iPod & earbuds--everybody listens to their own music as we dance walk around the park loop. What is "Dance Walking"? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. Check out this funny and smart article published about the Dance Walk in Prospect Park: 

http://themomtropolis.com/dance-walk-you-know-you-want-to/
results.how_to_find_us: Standing in Grand Army Plaza, walk away from the Arch, into the park entrance. Walk up the drive about 50 paces. We meet on the grassy triangle, just shy of the park loop.
results.name: Dance Walk in Prospect Park--Saturday April 23 @10am

results.description:
The hike is ON.  There may be occasional showers, so bring rain gear just in case.


MEET EVENT LEADER: James Schlegel,[masked]
Meet: 10 AM Tulip Springs parking lot to the right and back
by the picnic area off Cherry Lane, a continuation of Cherry Lane/Brookside Ave., 
Millburn/West Orange north of S. Orange Ave. A mix of trails depending on
conditions for about 4 miles at a moderate pace. Hiking boots required. Rain will cancel the hike. Watch this site on the morning of April 23 for any last minute changes/cancellations.

If this is your third trial meetup event with the TSR Meetup group, we now ask you to join our TriState Ramblers Club for $15 for a yearly membership. By paying the club membership fee you will have a FULLER SCHEDULE of hikes, bike rides, and canoeing events 6 DAYS a week, all year long. Visit our website at tsr.nynjtc.org for an application and schedule preview.

DIRECTIONS:
From north of the park (either eastbound or westbound) on I-280: Take exit 7. At the bottom of the ramp, Turn south (left) onto Pleasant Valley Way. Proceed 2.2 miles to the corner of Pleasant Valley Way and Northfield Ave. Continue straight, name changes to Cherry Lane toward Millburn. It is .08 miles to entrance on the left after the Northfield Ave intersection.
ALTERNATIVE: From South Orange Ave go 0.4 miles north on Cherry Lane, a continuation of Brookside. Entrance is on the east side of the road. Make an immediate right hand turn to Tulip Springs parking.
results.name: HIKE - Tulip Springs/So. Mtn Reservation, West Orange

results.description:
This is the South East Bronx, located directly over East Harlem on the 6 Train to Brook Avenue. I love this community, it has been through a great amount. I am so proud of the progress its made after the Giuliani years. The neighborhood is thriving and still maintain its rustic roaring 40s look. 


Iglesia Bautista Misionera ( Missionary Baptist Church)  is located in the heart of the South East Bronx, ran by Jose Quinones, the congregation holds several programs to assist the community meet some of their challenges.


Join us as we assist the staff prepare and serve food, as well as keep speak to come of the community as they are tested for HIV and receive a free meal. Spanish speakers are welcome, but all volunteers are requested. Come and help create a comfortable environment while members of the community get tested and receive a free meal. This is a great way to encourage local community members to want to be tested and to feel a larger community presence

http://www.queenslibrary.org/sites/default/files/blog-images/dreamstime_xs_24050301.jpg?1355769010


Take the local 6 train to Brook Ave. The church is right around the block from the train station.


Please contact[masked] or [masked]

FREE Circuit Training Saturdays! A 50-minute non-stop intense workout. You will sweat off the weight, you will burn calories, you will gain muscle. All levels welcome. We vow to never give up on you. For we will do everything in our power to help you reach your goal. We operate in a judgement free zone to facilitate your comfort. We promise you will progress.

This Class consist of running, walking, floor exercise, abdominal  workouts, squats, jumprope, and much more. You always have the option to perform the modified version of any drill! This allows beginners or anyone with a minor injury to comfortable fit right in. Build your strength and endurance to perform the unmodified versions of the drill when you see FIT (pun intended :)!! All while moving to be beat of the music. Bring your family, bring your friends.

results.description:
RSVP'S CLOSED

PLEASE READ THIS CAREFULLY BEFORE YOU RSVP. I TAKE THE RSVP PROCESS VERY SERIOUSLY AND I EXPECT THAT YOU SHOULD TOO. THIS EVENT WILL BE POSTED VIA A LAST MINUTE E-MAIL BY SAT APRIL 16 SO IF YOU RECEIVE THOSE E-MAILS, PLEASE REMOVE YOUR RSVP IMMEDIATELY.

Join me and AMC dues paying Club members who do not have to RSVP unless you do not get last minute hiking info from Yahoo on a fun, interesting, fast paced hiking tour of around 8-9 miles. MEETING DETAILS WILL BE SENT BY E-MAIL TO THOSE WHO RSVP THURSDAY NIGHT APRIL 21. We already did Part II in October 2015. (I count backwards!) In Part II we visited the High Bridge and then headed North. This time, Part I, we are going to visit the High Bridge from the South.

Closed for some 40 years, the High Bridge recently opened up. It spans the Harlem River and connects Manhattan to the Bronx and was once used to bring water from the Croton Aqueduct to New York City. (The Manhattan Boro President said “This is almost the eighth wonder of the world” and that is one great exaggeration but it is pretty cool to walk over it.) Before we visit the High Bridge we’ll tour Riverside Park, we’ll then see the the amazing Viaduct,  travel thru what was once the old village of Manhattanville and then we’ll stop very briefly for lunch at Riverbank State Park. There will be some spectacular views of the Hudson River along the way. We will move at a fast pace but we’ll stop for a very short while a number of times to talk about what we see. Much of the hike will be along the waterfront. In addition, right before we get to the High Bridge, we’ll visit what was once the little village of Carmansville located in the West 150’s and then we’ll walk back and forth over the High Bridge. WE WILL THEN CLIMB UP ONE HUGE FLIGHT OF STAIRS-trust me this is the best way to do this for a number of reasons-and then we’ll finish up at a subway station. THERE IS GOING TO BE A LOT OF SURPRISES ON THIS ONE.

BRING LUNCH AND WATER. NO FOOD STOPS TO BUY LUNCH. PLAN ON FINISHING BEFORE DINNER. (That means I’m not sure when we will finish-maybe around 5 or so?!)

We will meet BEFORE 10:30 A.M. to sign in. WE LEAVE PROMPTLY.

Meeting place will be close to a subway.

I bet you stopped reading by now-if not earlier! KEEP GOING-EXERT YOURSELF A LITTLE BIT.

Please consider joining the Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC) http://www.amc-ny.org/ The Club offers many hikes, walks and events and is also active in conservation efforts and trail maintenance. Only a few of the many hikes and walks that are offered by AMC leaders are posted on Meetup. Since this event will be posted as a last minute hike to AMC Club members, there is NO need for AMC club members to RSVP for this-unless you don’t get last minute e-mails from Yahoo. (Contact me a few days before the hike if you are a dues paying AMC Club member and don’t get these e-mails and I’ll tell you how). Let’s leave 10 spaces for AMC Meetup members.

Needless to say, please take the RSVP process seriously and be considerate. SPACE IS LIMITED. If you have been a NO SHOW on any previous AMC Meetup event that I have led or are an abuser of the RSVP process–see your Attendance History- please do not sign up for this event because I am just going to delete your RSVP. Let someone else go who will actually show up. SOME PRIORITY WILL BE GIVEN TO THOSE WHO HAVE PREVIOUSLY ATTENDED OTHER AMC MEETUP EVENTS THAT I HAVE LED OR ORIGINALLY SIGNED UP FOR THIS EVENT ON APRIL 9. I ONLY KEEP A WAIT LIST FOR A SHORT TIME.

I am going to ask that people not post any comments or questions prior to the event. You have more than enough information to do this once you get the meeting details. No offense, but I don’t need to know-and probably neither does anyone else- what you are doing that day if you can’t make it or what you think the weather will be. AFTER the event, post as many comments and photos as you like.

If the weather forecast is really bad, See the Accuweather website like I do, I will post a notice on the day of the hike by 8:00 A.M. If there is no notice, we go. We will finish at the A subway station at 175 th Street.

ON APRIL 30, I WILL BE LEADING A HIKE ON ROOSEVELT ISLAND DURING THE CHERRY BLOSSOM FESTIVAL.
results.name: The High Bridge from the South! (Part I)-Rescheduled

We like to ask you for a donation of $1.00 to help cover the cost of using Meetup's web page to announce this hike.
Hope to cya there.

results.description:
With the weather warming up, we're ready to kick off our 2016 campaign! First practice will be this Saturday at Worlds Fair Marina. Space is limited so please RSVP if you plan on attending. 

We will start with a warm up run and then go over the basics of dragon boat paddle technique followed by approximately 60 mins of boat time. Please bring your running shoes and dress appropriately for the weather. Rash guards, paddling jackets if you have it, would be helpful gear. You should prepare to get a little wet, so bring a towel and a change of clothes. Additionally, bring some water or gatorade. For new paddlers, we will provide the paddle and personal flotation device. Please allow for up to 3 hours for each practice session.

Note that boat space is limited and we want to make sure everyone gets a fair chance to practice. Each seat and RSVP is precious so we have to be sticklers with attendance. That means we take our RSVPs seriously and will reserve the right to remove no shows from this meetup group.
results.name: First Practice - 2016

results.description:
PLEASE BRING BOTH A BLUE T-SHIRT & A WHITE T-SHIRT.                                                                                                                                                                                 Started by a group of soccer fanatics who love to play the Beautiful Game and wanted to create a meetup for individuals of all levels. 

Our Mission: Play safe, get your workout on & HAVE FUN!!

The Lowdown: 

1. Play safe,  games are 7v7 including goalie, NO slide tackles, excessive aggression will NOT be tolerated (the precinct is across the street...LOL!!).  

2. Cleats are permitted, and Sneakers or Turf Shoes are acceptable as well. We play for an hour with a break in the middle. If no volunteered goal keeper, players will rotate the position. We play with corner kicks and throw-ins. Also, everyone should bring a Blue T-Shirt AND a White T-Shirt.

3. Pitch Location: Between Baxter & Mulberry St.with additional entrance on Worth & Bayard St. 

4. Nearest train stations: Brooklyn Bridge (4, 5 & 6), Canal Street (A, B, C, Q, R, N & 6), Chambers Street (J and Z). Citibike station is available right next to the field on Worth Street. 

5. HAVE FUN!

See you Downtown! 

Terms and Conditions of the participating in our group:

PLEASE READ THESE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF USE CAREFULLY. 
BY USING THIS WEBSITE, YOU AGREE TO THESE TERMS AND CONDITIONS. 

JOINING AND SIGNING UP FOR DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT: 

I certify that I am 18 years of age or older and that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore I, individually, hereby release and discharge, DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER Organizers and Co-organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER programs or activities. 

DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER Organizer and its Co-Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

The Downtown Pickup Soccer Team

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Dr. Jeff Jones will provide a brief introduction to Penrose diagrams (also known as conformal diagrams), and then we'll use them to analyze the causal structure of a black hole. One of the most puzzling things about black holes is that it seems as if either the Equivalence Principle of general relativity or the Uncertainty Principle from quantum mechanics must be violated in order for them to be consistent. However, the Black Hole Complementarity hypothesis says that perhaps neither is violated and yet there are two very different quantum theories of black holes, one from an external perspective and one from an internal perspective, where these theories are dual and "complementary" to each other in the same sense that waves and particles were viewed by Bohr as dual and complementary to each other.

suggested reference:
https://arxiv.org/pdf/hep-th/9306069v2

Please note:
The NY Quantum Theory Meetup group is most thankful to ThoughtWorks for gracefully allowing us to use their premises. Meetup participants are request to be respectful and considerate of those premises and all other people therein. Thanks.
results.name: Black Hole Complementarity

results.description:
Dear friends, 

We are very happy to invite you to the exhibition tour and talk of the Italian photographer Luigi Ghirri :

"The impossible Landascape" 

The exhibition takes its title from his 1989 artist’s statement about the way photographs “become our impossible landscape, without scale, without a geographic order to orient us; a tangle of monuments, lights, thoughts, objects, moments, analogies from our landscape of the mind, which we seek out, even unconsciously, every time we look out a window, into the openness of the outside world, as if they were the points of an imaginary compass that indicates a possible direction.” 

The exhibition includes thirty-four vintage color photographs in their small peculiar format made between 1970 and 1989 of landscapes from Italy, where the artist was born and where he spent most of his life, and also includes photographs from France and Austria as well. 

During his career Luigi Ghirri has tried to build an identity of the places by creating an inseparable emotional connection with them. He transforms the ordinary in extraordinary, the familiar becomes strange and in each photograph there is always a sensation of wonder given by the rediscovery and reinterpretation of the subject.

Join us for a journey into Italian photography !!!

Ticket: $10 can be purchased HERE


MANDATORY RSVP at [masked]
results.name: New York Italians  Art Tour : LUIGI GHIRRI!

results.description:
WHO:

All members

WHAT:

* For the Sake of My Sanity: One Woman's Journey of Speaking Truth to Power and Ignorance by DrLoni


Sake presents select pieces of spoken-word created during the author's coming of age from adolescence to adulthood and then deconstructs them through a reflective lens. It chronicles DrLoni's use of writing as a vehicle to connect with her inner strength. The book begins with -- End White Silence -- a piece she published during her tenure as a university professor. One of the book's most important pieces is -- Grandparents Love -- a touching tribute to her grandparents. The book ends with -- A Call to Action -- a fiery spoken-word piece which challenges society to honestly love and educate our children. Even within its difficult moments, Sake brims with ample doses of love for humanity.

(From Amazon.com)

* At this time to book is available via Amazon, iBooks and Createspace.

Calling all poets! Jersey City Writers is now offering a weekly poetry workshop. 

This workshop will start by critiquing 2-3 poems, one by each person signed up ahead of time. The workshop will end, if time permits, with one 10 minute writing prompt (an idea to incorporate into a poem written on the spot).  Poets who sign up to be workshopped must email Sarah poem by 10am Friday so she can print copies for the group. To sign up for a workshop in advance, please contact Sarah Jewell at [masked]. 

While workshopping poems, we will “mind our P’s and Q’s” by Praising first what works in a poem, and then Questioning what might be improved. This helps to keep the feedback positive and constructive. If you are new to critiquing poetry, please see these guidelines:

results.description:
THE THREE POISONS - LOVING KINDNESS AND COMPASSION AS ANTIDOTES

It is all too easy to consider kindness a secondary virtue, the one we reach for only as a last resort. But if we look at the strength of kindness--the way it reminds us of a sense of inner abundance, the way it helps us feel connected to others instead of isolated and apart--we can appreciate kindness as the force it is. Kindness isn’t an ally of foolishness or gullibility, but rather an ally of wisdom and courage.

Sharon Salzberg

This week we will look at Loving-Kindness and Compassion as they relate to our previous discussion of Aversion and Hatred.

Last time we saw that our perceptions seem to tell us that the “I” we know as our self is separate and exists independently from everything that isn't me. We often feel that things outside of our separate self are threats and require protective actions and those actions are often motivated by our anger or hatred of those external objects.

In Buddhist teachings, this perceived separateness between "me" and "other" is considered to be a misperception or delusion that masks a deeper reality of unity or oneness and lack of separation. It is through direct experience of this universal oneness that the states of Loving-Kindness and Compassion arise naturally in us.

In the Loving-Kindness practice we understand that just as we wish to be happy, healthy, safe and live with ease, so does every fellow being. Similarly, in the Compassion practice we cultivate an understanding that we all have suffering or dissatisfaction in life and wish an end to it for ourselves and other beings. The instructions for these two practices are simple, but living them directly and earnestly in meditation is what opens our hearts and awakens our minds.

I hope you'll share your Saturday morning with us.

Class Structure:  

Each class begins with a very brief guided meditation of gathering and quieting followed by a topical teaching and an expanded guided mindfulness meditation. There is time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. 

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: The Three Poisons - Loving-Kindness and Compassion as Antidotes

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

Paul

results.description:
Hi every pony! Let's continue getting April going by having another adventure with a wonderful trotting meetup. This one will be in the shimmering lights of Manehattan for all you local NY Bronies and also for those who like traveling in looking to see more of the Big Apple~!

This go around we are going up to the tip of Manehattan: our lovely Washington Heights! It is named for Fort Washington, a fortification that had been constructed at the highest point of Manhattan by the Continental Army troops during the American Revolutionary War[masked]), as to defend the area from the British forces. We will be meeting at NY Penn station and from there taking the 1 train uptown to 157th street. There we will be starting our trot walking along side of the Trinity Cemetery (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity_Church_Cemetery) to the Hudson River Greenway.
We will be working our way up north on the Greenway all the way to the Inwood Hill Park! (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inwood_Hill_Park)
After completing the trot we will get down into a new local eatery to cool down, chat, relax, and regain our energy from our successful hike before we break off and say our farewells. No one is obligated to stay if they are scheduled to be somewhere else though ^^.


We will leave 30 minutes, past the hour. So please get there EARLY!
NOTE: We will NOT be waiting on anyone past 12:30 PM. It is unfair for those who get here early, so please plan to get here early. If you will be late, please Un-RSVP from the event, catching up with the rest of the group would be neigh impossible.

Notice about necessary fare: For use, the NYC subway will cost $2.75 per ride.

It is important to keep well hydrated. Bringing along some bottled water is advisable. There is some water fountains in the parks, but the first option is highly recommended, this time.
Other recommendations would be possibly a light snack if you get a munchies moment while on the hike, also a small towel.
Any other questions or recommendations, please let us know in the comments! Phone number will be posted on the morning of the Meetup. We look forward to seeing every pony again! ^^

MORE INFORMATION WILL BE COMING SOON!!!
results.name: The Trotting Crusaders of NYC

Surviving as an artist in the modern age is tricky. With a little bit of strategy and discipline, you can survive—and even thrive—as an artist and creator.


"Thrive As An Artist," a Financial Literacy Workshop for Artists, has partnered with Mike Geffner Presents The Inspired Word to host a THREE-part event where Artists can perform at our Open Mic and learn how to thrive financially!


Attendees will be able to participate in an Open Mic where they will have the opportunity to perform their original material, and then stay to participate in a Financial Literacy Workshop hosted by David Sharp, author of “The Thriving Artist. " This workshop will discuss the financial needs and concerns of freelance artists and attendees will learn how to plan, save and budget for their dreams.


*****NO COVER & ALL AGESRSVP required to Attend.Dates: 4/23, 5/7 & 6/11Mic Signup @ 12:00pmPerformances & Workshop begins: 1:00pmWhere: Capital One 360 Café - 968 3rd AvenueManhattan, New York 10022


****Water and snacks will be provided*****


Performance slots are limited so if you are looking to participate in the Open Mic we STRONGLY suggest you arrive early to guarantee your performance slot as this Open Mic will be first come first serve. To create a PG environment all material must be clean and radio friendly. There is limited space for this workshop, so RSVP's are required.


*****


Backline Provided: Yamaha PA, Three Shure Mics, Alesis QS7 Keyboard & a Roland Jazz Guitar Amp.


*****


Directions By Subway: Take the 4,5,6,N,Q,R to 59th St & Lexington. The Cafe is located on the corner of E 58th & 3rd Avenue.


*****


Founded by longtime NYC journalist Mike Geffner in January 2010, The Inspired Word is an open mic/literary/performance series that has featured Grammy, Golden Globe, Tony, and Obie Award winners as well as Emmy nominated actors, American Idol and America's Got Talent finalists, and HBO stars.

An afternoon of brunch, cocktails and #BossBabe panel speakers set against the beautiful Manhattan skyline underneath the Williamsburg bridge. New York is all about community and nothing says community better than an afternoon of female empowerment.


#girlBOSSnyc April theme and launch event is Spring Cleaning: Cleaning from the Inside Out. 

Panel Speakers include: 

Kassidy Brown


We are the XX, Co-Founder

www.wearethexx.com

Tiffany Hardin


Founder of Gild Creative Group and She Knows Now.

www.tiffanyhardin.com

Danielle Mercurio

Meditation and Life Transformation Coach and Author

wwww.daniellemercurio.com

Brunch Boxes provided by Culinary Chrissy, Personal Chef
Drinks provided by Bronx Brewery, La Ferme Julien Rose, and Balance Water. 

More Vendors to Come! 

ABOUT #girlBOSSnyc
We have found over the years that as female entrepreneurs in the film, music, fashion and blogging world it can be tough finding the time to cultivate real and authentic relationships with other strong females in New York. We yearn for likeminded budding and established women who want to have fun (cocktails) but also those that want to create and inspire each other with passionate projects and events. 


Hence why we started a networking group called #girlBOSSnyc. We are a social network of empowered and inspired NYC women supporting community, careers and each other. Our goal is to have monthly passion and purpose filled events that cultivate friendship and conversation amongst other ladies who are really busy like us. Most of the women in our networking group are writers, bloggers, PR execs, fashion, film, art, and music young professionals. We look forward to seeing you at this and all upcoming events.

Event Description:


This is a Day Hike, not a backpacking trip.  I will be bringing 3 or 4 fully loaded backpacking kits representing various gear philosophies from traditional to ultralight.  Participants will have the opportunity to take turns carrying each pack to experience the impact of gear selection on comfort while hiking. We will stop along the hike to demonstrate different types of shelters, cooking systems, and water filtration systems.

****THE 9AM AND NOON EVENTS ARE EXACTLY THE SAME. PLEASE DO NOT SIGN UP FOR BOTH!****

Participants are encouraged to bring equipment that they have questions about, but shouldn't feel like they need to go out and purchase gear.  Our objective is to see and try out gear in the field before you make expensive investments.

This is the first part in a series of Intro to Backpacking events which will hopefully culminate in a section hike along the Appalachian Trail. 


Suggested Reading:

Ray Jardin's "Trail Life"

Ryan Jordan's "Lightweight Backpacking & Camping"

Andrew Skurka's "The Ultimate Hiker's Gear Guide"

Section Hiker's Backpacking Blog

CampingJay

Syllabus


Hike Description:

Distance: ~7 Miles

Hiking Time: 6 to 8 hours, including stops.

Attractions: Two scenic lakes, panoramic views, Bald Rocks

Highest Elevation: 1,380

Elevation Gain: ~2,500 feet

Parking Coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Map: NYNJTC Harriman Bear Mountain Trails - Map #118 & 199

Route Description:

Long Path (Aqua) to Dunning (Yellow) to Ramapo-Dunderberg (Red) to Bald Rocks Shelter. Then, Ramapo-Dunderberg (Red) to Long Path (Aqua) to Dunning (Yellow) to Arden Surebridge (Red Triangle)

Recommended Day Hiking Gear:

The 10 Essentials

CampingJay's Gear List


NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear. Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
“For the dead and the living, we must bear witness.” – Elie Wiesel, Holocaust Survivor, Nobel Peace Laureate, Boston University Professor

New York Farm Animal Save is a grassroots, vegan organization with an aim to hold vigils and bear witness to animals who are about to be slaughtered for food. If you have never heard of The Save Movement, it started with Toronto Pig Save back in December 2010 when a woman named Anita Krajnc noticed trucks of frightened pigs being transported to a nearby slaughterhouse. By July 2011, three vigils were held each week for pigs, chickens, and cows. 

I had the opportunity to visit Toronto this month and was able to attend each one of the vigils. It is difficult to describe this experience, but it was one that forever changed me. It is one thing to hear about animal suffering and watch videos documenting it, but being present with these sentient beings while they are experiencing immense pain and trauma is entirely another and reinforces the reality that this injustice is truly an everyday occurrence. It made the situation that much more urgent and gave me motivation to fight even harder for animals.

We found out about NY Farm Animal Save and decided it would be great to attend their events and provide support! Their monthly vigil is held outside La Granja Live Poultry. The main purpose of the event is to bear witness to the animals, document the conditions they are in, and educate the public about veganism. The Animal Save Movement utilizes a love-based approach inspired by Leo Tolstoy and Mahatma Gandhi. 

There is also a NJ Farm Animal Save, and we would like to attend their next event, so keep an eye out for that! Hope to see you there!

“When the suffering of another creature causes you to feel pain, do not submit to the initial desire to flee from the suffering one, but on the contrary, come closer, as close as you can to him who suffers, and try to help.” – Leo Tolstoy, A Calendar of Wisdom
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet at the Hoboken PATH station 11 am. If you want to go on your own, we can meet you there at noon. We will be easy to spot because there will be many activists with signs.
results.name: NY Farm Animal Save Vigil #28

Acoustic Guitar for Beginners 101Four 90-Minute Sessions Held on 4 consecutive Saturdays.
FEBRUARY-MARCH - [APRIL 9, 16, 23, 30 -- 12:30pm]


WHO CAN ATTEND:
Beginning guitar students who have no prior knowledge of how to play guitar, or people who can play, but are unfamiliar with how to read and play from written notes.  NOTE:  Session #1 is MANDATORY for participation in the Series.


WHAT YOU WILL LEARN:
Learn to READ and PLAY NOTES, CHORDS and PLAY SONGS you know and love.  And what you learn is applicable to playing Rock, Blues, Folk, Country, Jazz, Classical or any other type of music the student is interested in playing.

MONTHLY, FOUR-WEEK CYCLES:
In this workshop, a specific set of concepts will be covered over a period of 4-week.  Each monthly, 4-week period will be closed to people who did not attend the 1st session of the month.  This allow the group to continue to progress through the lesson material and avoid the need to review all that came before each time a new person joins the group. There will be three to four monthly, 4-week cycles before the first cycle is repeated


WHAT TO BRING:
• Bring your own guitar for these lessons
• Also bring a three-ring binder and a pencil

COST:  The cost of this session is $15.00, which must be paid when you RSVP. 


IMPORTANT NOTE: If there are 5 or less people registered for this meetup, we will not meet at Ripley Grier Studios.  We will instead meet at the Sony Public Atrium, 550 Madison Avenue (Between 55th and 56th Street on Madison).  Watch for an email confirming where we will meet.

You know our group is all about fun, laughter and excitement.  We will talk about relationships, the good, the bad and the ugly and just enjoy spending time with each other.

Yes, we will be talking about men and partners and funny stories that will make your toes curl.  My stories alone will have you laughing out loud!  As the weather turns, come out into the warmth of other Curvy Girls!  

Take a break from all that makes us busy and spend time with women who actually get you!

Here is the menu for your perusal:  

http://cafeteriagroup.com/home/


****PS, every curvy girl leaves with a SURPRISE sexy gift compliments of Curvy Girls in the City and their supporters!!!!!!!!

GO BIG OR GO HOME!!!

Precious
Creator, Curvy Girls in the City

results.description:
Due to popular demand, let's re-screen “Alone in Fukushima.” This doc chronicles the astonishing story of Naoto Matsumura, who struggles to survive the radiation with the numerous animals abandoned inside the evacuated zone surrounding the Fukushima nuclear plant meltdown. It really was a beautiful and heartbreaking film, very simply made but extremely compelling. 

This time Director/Editor/Cinematographer Mayu Nakamura will address us by video following the film. 

Tickets are $15 and are available online, by phone [masked]), and in person at CRS. http://bit.ly/1UlM5Td

ALONE IN FUKUSHIMA
(2014, Japanese w/ English subtitles, 98′)

Ostriches, cows, hogs, cats, a pony and a dog…Animals roam freely in lush greenery in the evacuated nuclear zone. And there is one man who stayed behind, creating his own Eden. 55 year-old Naoto Matsumura lives alone with these animals in Tomioka, a town located only 12 kilometers away from the melted-down nuclear power plant. In the last few years, Naoto has been the focus of media attention, being covered by CNN, ARTE and other major overseas networks. But due to government restrictions, his story has remained largely untold in the Japanese media. 

https://youtu.be/HRhl4u-_AG4


Until now, there has never been a feature-length documentary film on him and the reality of life in the exclusion zone. An accidental hero or a fool on the hill? Naoto is an ever-intriguing, complex person who has firmly remained behind in his hometown-a place Japan is trying to erase from the map. “Alone in Fukushima” follows his life with animals in the zone over the course of a year.

http://aloneinfukushima.com

Learn From 3.11 was founded in 2011 to create an opportunity for people to study together about the actual situations in the disaster-stricken area and the related radiation problems by periodically holding seminars and events.
results.how_to_find_us: above Think Coffee (look for the brown door to the right/south of Think and ring the bottom buzzer)
results.name: Screen & Discuss Alone in Fukushima

Please make sure what you are bringing is totally vegan! Read the back of EVERYTHING! Some chips contain milk powder and casein. Some other foods have lard, animal fats, honey, etc. So just be mindful of the food you bring.

Can't wait to grub with y'all! Please write what you are bringing in the comments below.

OH! and Amanda Hinds is an amazing Vegan pioneer documenting vegans from all over the world. She is coming all the way from England and wants to interview more vegans of color about being vegan, vegan tips, or anything you want to share about your experience so please come right at 1pm if you want to be pulled aside for an interview. results.description:
Sripraphai... Try saying or figuring out how to pronounce that name. It's a top notch Thai restaurant and if you are a Zagat follower it is one of the top rated Thai restaurants in our city. I have been hearing about this legendary restaurant for many years and have never taken the trek. I am a huge fan of Thai food and this one is the one that I have sadly, unintentionally neglected. Join Frank and I as we take this trek to much the lauded SriPraPhai for their exceptional goodness from the motherland.


Thai is one of my favorite cuisines. It is one of the most flavorful cuisines out there using the formula of sour, sweet, bitter, salty and spicy in their equation. Indian cuisine is very similar in this regard but Thai takes it to another level. With great classics like papaya salad, varieties of tom yum, assorted recipes including fried fish and amazing desserts, you are in for a tasty culinary adventure.

One of my aim's here also is to get Frank away from perpetually ordering "Drunken Noodles" every single time and thinking "Yeah, I Know Thai Food" Thai cuisine takes alot of the great base ingredients in the world like peanuts, curry, lime, fish, chicken, string beans etc and does magical things with them.

Come join us for this journey in flavor, education, and general love of food at one of the best to ever do it; Sripraphai in Woodside Queens. You won't regret it.


P.S. They also cater to vegetarians/vegans so everyone is welcome in this pool.


• Note: This restaurant gives no phuks about silly things like reservations or credit cards so please,  If you are coming on this trek out to the cultural food mecca that is Queens, make sure you keep your RSVP updated so we are not waiting for you unnecessarily.


• Also come with a wad of cash equivalent to your appetite. This area is NOT big bank friendly so while you may find a bodega with an ATM it's best to come prepared with cash in pocket or lady bag.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be inside the restaurant waiting for everyone. Remember. There are NO RESERVATIONS. Please be on time or let us know if you are running late or we will start without you. Remember This is Cash Only so bring some dough.
results.name: Get Thai'd Up @ Sripraphai [Woodside, Queens]

results.description:
From Goodreads--
Olga Grushin's astonishing literary debut has won her comparisons with everyone from Gogol to Nabokov. A virtuoso study in betrayal and its consequences, it explores - really, colonizes - the consciousness of Anatoly Sukhanov, who many years before abandoned the precarious existence of an underground artist for the perks of a Soviet apparatchik. But, at the age of 56, his perfect life is suddenly disintegrating. Buried dreams return to haunt him. New political alignments threaten to undo him.

Vaulting effortlessly from the real to the surreal and from privilege to paranoia, The Dream Life of Sukhanov is a darkly funny, demonically entertaining novel.


The total vote was--
The Dream Life of Sukhanov by Olga Grushin--10
The Sellout by Paul Beatty--7
Delirium by Laura Restrepo--3
results.name: April -- The Dream Life of Sukhanov by Olga Grushin

Join us tomorrow to put a little SALSA in your life. 

Each and every saturday we have a little salsa for all ages and all levels.

Kid's are welcome to join the "Latin Kids Ensemble" from 1-2pm.  In this class kids learn about Latin Culture and its rhythm.  We focus on teaching them the roots of music and how to feel it in their souls. 

• Salsa Level 1: 2-3PM

Two left feet? Never danced before? Want to learn how to salsa? Come join us.. No experience necessary, and no partner needed. Just bring your dancing shoes, and your positive energy y VAMOS A BAILAR!!! WHEPPA!!!

• Salsa Level 2: 3-4PM 

Salsa Level 2 requires you to have previous salsa experience. You should know the fundamentals of the basics, and an open mind to learn.  In this class we will cover footwork, partner-work, body movement, spinning, and styling techniques.

Learn to Salsa New York Style with Yrma Arias at El Taller! This style of Salsa, "On 2", has gained popularity over the last decade in NYC. The classes will focus on the look and feel of the dance - with an emphasis on timing, footwork and partner work. Classes will provide instruction and repetition of the steps ‘Shines’, introduce the importance of the leader/follower connection, and provide practical techniques for the Latin Motion. Particular attention is paid to rhythm and musicality. This is an enjoyable class designed for people of all ages. The most important lesson is to have fun! What to bring: A great attitude and comfortable clothes and shoes that allow you to move!


When you arrive at 215 E. 99th Street, press the El T button on the intercom and we'll buzz you right in!

Once upstairs, look for members with laptops, tablets, or phones with Hearthstone. We are hoping to secure one of the long wooden tables to accommodate our group but there is also a board game meetup and knitting club that might be occupying the space. If the long wooden tables are unavailable, we'll go to the back where all the glass windows are and arrange some tables and chairs together.

Ideal train to get here is the A,C,E,2,3 at Chambers Street. It's about 2 blocks from there. This space has lots of seating, and Wi-Fi is solid. It will require repeated login to their whole foods network every two hours.  You can also bring your phones for more consistent internet.
